5. Exclude mimics (evaluate for autonomic failure, cerebellar signs, cortical features).

Neuroimaging Pearls

- “Hummingbird sign”: sagittal midbrain flattening relative to the pons.
• “Penguin silhouette”: axial midbrain tegmentum thinning.
• MR Parkinsonism Index (pons area/midbrain area × MCP diameter/SCP diameter) >1.0 suggests PSP.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Levodopa yields minimal benefit in PSP. Symptomatic management includes amantadine for rigidity, SSRIs for mood, physical therapy for gait, and supportive measures (e.g., occupational therapy).

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 1 2020 exam. Atypical parkinsonian syndromes with early falls and ocular motor dysfunction are commonly tested on board examinations, often with an associated MRI image illustrating midbrain atrophy.

question_text: Regarding essential palatal myoclonus, which of the following statements is true?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2018] Essential palatal myoclonus (also called isolated palatal tremor) is a focal myoclonus of the soft palate without an identifiable structural lesion. Key concepts:
• Palatal muscle anatomy: tensor veli palatini (innervated by V3) versus levator veli palatini (innervated by vagus), with essential tremor arising from tensor veli palatini hyperactivity.
• Triangular circuit (Guillain–Mollaret triangle): dentate nucleus → red nucleus → inferior olive → back to cerebellum; lesions here produce symptomatic palatal myoclonus with hypertrophic olivary degeneration.
• Sleep physiology: essential palatal myoclonus ceases during non-REM and REM sleep, distinguishing it from symptomatic forms that persist through sleep.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Essential palatal myoclonus is characterized by rhythmic contractions of tensor veli palatini generating an audible click. Surface EMG studies (Ondo et al., Neurology 1994) demonstrate bursts of 50–150 ms that reliably cease with onset of sleep in 100% of cases. In contrast, symptomatic palatal myoclonus—due to hypertrophic olivary degeneration from lesions in the Guillain–Mollaret triangle—persists during sleep and shows MRI evidence of T2 hyperintensity and enlargement of the inferior olivary nucleus (Goyal et al., Radiology 2000). Current Movement Disorder Society classifications (2018) uphold cessation during sleep as the pathognomonic feature distinguishing essential from symptomatic palatal myoclonus.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Hypertrophy of the ipsilateral olivary nucleus
• Incorrect: Essential type shows normal olivary anatomy. Hypertrophic olivary degeneration (HOD) occurs contralateral to the cerebellar lesion in symptomatic palatal myoclonus.
C. Pathology involving the triangle of Mollaret
• Incorrect: Lesions in the dentato-rubro-olivary circuit underlie symptomatic palatal myoclonus, not the essential form.
D. Responds well to anticonvulsant therapy
• Incorrect: Essential palatal myoclonus is often refractory to systemic anticonvulsants; targeted botulinum toxin injection yields superior relief (Ressler et al., Mov Disord 2007).

Comparison Table

FeatureEssential Palatal MyoclonusSymptomatic Palatal Myoclonus
Muscle involvedTensor veli palatini (V3)Levator veli palatini (vagus)
MRI findingsNormal inferior oliveHypertrophic olivary degeneration on T2
Sleep effectCeases during sleepPersists through sleep
PathophysiologyIdiopathic central generatorDeafferentation of Guillain–Mollaret triangle
First-line therapyBotulinum toxin injectionTreat underlying lesion; benzos/clonazepam

Clinical Pearls

- Listen for a synchronous “ear click” in essential palatal myoclonus due to Eustachian tube oscillation.
• Surface EMG during polysomnography confirms cessation of palatal bursts in sleep.
• Local botulinum toxin injection into tensor veli palatini (10–30 U) offers targeted relief with minimal systemic side effects.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Equating “palatal tremor” with essential palatal myoclonus: always confirm sleep cessation to rule out symptomatic form.
2. Assuming olivary hypertrophy localizes ipsilaterally; in symptomatic cases, the affected inferior olive is contralateral to the cerebellar or brainstem lesion.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. Mulligan et al., J Neurol Sci 2022: Prospective open-label trial (n=24) of botulinum toxin A in essential palatal myoclonus reported 80% reduction in click frequency and significant quality-of-life improvement at 3-month follow-up (Level IIa).
2. Serrano et al., Mov Disord 2020: EMG polysomnography study showed sleep cessation of palatal myoclonic bursts in 100% of essential cases versus 0% in symptomatic, reinforcing diagnostic criteria (Level IIb).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Essential palatal myoclonus arises from hyperactivity of the trigeminal motor nucleus innervating tensor veli palatini. Symptomatic type involves the Guillain–Mollaret triangle: dentate nucleus → red nucleus (central tegmental tract) → inferior olive → cerebellum.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

- Essential: Central pacemaker within pontine tegmentum drives rhythmic trigeminal motor discharge without structural lesion.
• Symptomatic: Deafferentation-induced trans-synaptic degeneration leads to hypertrophy and hyperexcitability of inferior olivary neurons, perpetuating tremor.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical history: inquire about audible clicks and sleep effect.
2. Physical exam: observe palatal movements, assess for other brainstem signs.
3. Surface EMG ± polysomnography: record burst activity during wake and sleep.
4. MRI brain with T2-weighted sequences: evaluate for olivary enlargement.
5. Classify and institute appropriate therapy (botulinum vs lesion-directed).

Neuroimaging Pearls

In symptomatic palatal myoclonus, MRI shows T2 hyperintensity and hypertrophy of the inferior olive 6–18 months after an inciting lesion. Essential type yields a normal MRI.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Botulinum toxin A into tensor veli palatini is first-line for essential palatal myoclonus (10–30 U, repeat every 3 months). Clonazepam may provide adjunctive benefit; standard anticonvulsants (valproate, levetiracetam) show limited efficacy.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part I 2018 exam. Palatal myoclonus is tested in neurology boards by contrasting essential versus symptomatic types, with sleep cessation and imaging findings as high-yield differentiators.

question_text: An elderly patient with a history of coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) two years ago presents with a six-month history of frequent falls and restricted upward gaze. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2021] Progressive supranuclear palsy (PSP) is a primary 4-repeat tauopathy characterized by early postural instability, symmetric akinetic-rigid parkinsonism, and vertical supranuclear gaze palsy. Vertical gaze is mediated by the rostral interstitial nucleus of the medial longitudinal fasciculus in the midbrain; degeneration here produces impaired upward and downward saccades. Differentiating PSP from vascular parkinsonism (predominant lower-body gait impairment, extensive white matter changes) or idiopathic Parkinson’s disease (asymmetry, rest tremor, levodopa responsiveness) relies on clinical features and MRI midbrain atrophy (“hummingbird” sign). Normal pressure hydrocephalus features gait apraxia, ventriculomegaly, and urinary incontinence without vertical gaze palsy. (120 words)

Evidence-Based Analysis

PSP is correct because early backward falls and vertical supranuclear gaze palsy within three years fulfill the Movement Disorder Society (MDS) criteria for probable PSP (Höglinger et al., Movement Disorders 2017; Level B evidence). MRI classically shows midbrain atrophy with a reduced midbrain-to-pons ratio and the “hummingbird” sign (Josephs et al., Neurology 2006). PSP patients exhibit poor or minimal levodopa response (Litvan et al., Neurology 1996). Tau pathology with four-repeat isoforms accumulates in subcortical nuclei, causing symmetric rigidity and ocular motor deficits. No disease-modifying therapies are approved; management remains supportive (Williams et al., Brain 2007).

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Vascular Parkinsonism
• Presents with lower-body parkinsonism (gait freezing, shuffling) but preserved vertical eye movements.
• Misconception: attributing falls to cerebrovascular disease despite intact gaze.
• Imaging: periventricular white matter hyperintensities, not midbrain atrophy.

C. Parkinson’s Disease
• Features asymmetric onset, rest tremor, and robust levodopa response; vertical gaze is intact until very late.
• Misconception: any parkinsonism equates to PD.
• Imaging: usually normal or mild nonspecific changes.

D. Normal Pressure Hydrocephalus
• Triad of gait apraxia (“magnetic gait”), dementia, urinary incontinence; no supranuclear gaze palsy.
• Misconception: attributing gait disturbance to hydrocephalus without assessing eye movements.
• Imaging: ventriculomegaly with disproportionately enlarged subarachnoid spaces (DESH), no midbrain shrinkage.

Comparison Table

FeaturePSPVascular ParkinsonismParkinson’s DiseaseNormal Pressure Hydrocephalus
FallsEarly, backward (<1 year)Gradual, gait freezingLate (>3 years), rareGait apraxia, magnetic gait
Gaze palsyVertical supranuclear palsyPreservedIntact (only late)Absent
Levodopa responsePoor/minimalMinimalGoodVariable
MRI findingsMidbrain atrophy, hummingbird signPeriventricular WMHsNormal or mild nonspecificVentriculomegaly, DESH

Clinical Pearls

- Early backward falls and vertical gaze palsy (<3 years) are hallmark features of PSP, distinguishing it from other parkinsonian syndromes.
• A midbrain-to-pons area ratio <0.52 on sagittal MRI and the “hummingbird” sign have high specificity (>90%) for PSP.
• PSP is a tauopathy; poor levodopa responsiveness is a key clinical discriminator.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Confusing early falls in PSP with advanced PD rather than recognizing them as an early red flag.
• Over-diagnosing vascular parkinsonism in patients with vascular risk factors without assessing vertical gaze.
• Neglecting MRI evaluation of midbrain size, which is essential for distinguishing PSP.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- Höglinger GU et al., Movement Disorder Society PSP Criteria, 2017: Establishes probable PSP diagnosis with early falls and vertical gaze palsy (Level B evidence).
• NICE Guideline CG35, 2017: Recommends MRI for atypical parkinsonism; highlights midbrain atrophy as a diagnostic marker in PSP (Level C recommendation).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Degeneration of the rostral interstitial nucleus of the medial longitudinal fasciculus in the dorsal midbrain disrupts vertical gaze. Tau accumulation in the substantia nigra, subthalamic nucleus, and globus pallidus produces symmetric rigidity and bradykinesia.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

PSP involves aggregation of four-repeat tau isoforms forming neurofibrillary tangles in subcortical structures and midbrain neurons, leading to neuronal loss, gliosis, and the clinical phenotype of gaze palsy and axial rigidity.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Identify early falls and vertical supranuclear gaze palsy clinically.
2. Obtain brain MRI: assess midbrain-to-pons ratio, look for hummingbird/morning glory signs.
3. Apply MDS-PSP diagnostic criteria for probable vs possible PSP.
4. Exclude alternative etiologies (vascular, hydrocephalus).
5. Initiate supportive therapies (physical, occupational, ocular exercises).

Neuroimaging Pearls

- Hummingbird sign: sagittal view midbrain atrophy with preserved pons.
• Morning glory sign: axial concavity of the midbrain tegmentum.
• Midbrain anteroposterior diameter <17 mm supports PSP diagnosis.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Levodopa trial (up to 1 g/day) often yields minimal benefit; lack of response aids diagnosis.
• Amantadine may provide modest gait improvement.
• Experimental tau-directed therapies (e.g., gosuranemab) are under investigation in clinical trials.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 1 2021 exam. Vertical supranuclear gaze palsy with early falls is a classic PSP presentation often tested in single-best-answer formats; familiarity with imaging signs and levodopa responsiveness is essential.

question_text: Which condition is characterized by chorea, cognitive decline, and behavioral changes?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2024] Huntington’s disease (HD) is an autosomal-dominant neurodegenerative disorder caused by CAG trinucleotide repeat expansion in the HTT gene. Core concepts:
• Basal ganglia circuits – degeneration of striatal GABAergic medium spiny neurons disrupts the indirect pathway, yielding chorea.
• Cognitive decline – frontal–subcortical network impairment causes executive dysfunction, memory loss, apathy.
• Behavioral changes – psychiatric manifestations (irritability, depression, disinhibition) often precede motor signs.
Students should recognize the classic triad (chorea + cognitive + psychiatric) and link it to striatal pathology and mutant huntingtin toxicity.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Huntington’s disease is the prototypical choreic disorder with progressive cognitive and psychiatric decline.
• Pathophysiology: Polyglutamine expansion (>39 repeats) in huntingtin triggers neuronal intranuclear inclusions, excitotoxicity, mitochondrial dysfunction, and selective loss of indirect pathway neurons in the caudate/putamen (Walker et al., 2015).
• Clinical presentation: Chorea often begins insidiously in mid-adult life, accompanied by executive dysfunction and mood disturbances (American Academy of Neurology [AAN], 2017).
• Diagnostic confirmation: PCR‐based CAG repeat analysis remains the gold standard (American College of Medical Genetics and Genomics [ACMG], 2022).
• Treatment guidelines: AAN 2017 practice guideline recommends tetrabenazine as first-line for chorea (Level B), with deutetrabenazine as alternative (Level B) given better side-effect profile.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Parkinson’s disease
• Incorrect because PD is primarily a hypokinetic rigid syndrome (bradykinesia, rigidity, resting tremor).
• Misconception: “Parkinsonian chorea” is actually dyskinesia from levodopa, not intrinsic chorea.
• Differentiator: PD shows nigrostriatal dopaminergic loss, Lewy bodies, and response to dopaminergic therapy.

C. Wilson’s disease
• Incorrect because Wilson’s features hepatic dysfunction, Kayser-Fleischer rings, dystonia, tremor (“wing-beating”), and psychiatric changes but rarely classical chorea.
• Misconception: All basal ganglia disorders cause chorea – Wilson’s more often causes dystonia.
• Differentiator: Serum ceruloplasmin low, 24-h urinary copper increased.

D. Multiple sclerosis
• Incorrect because MS presents with relapsing focal deficits (optic neuritis, sensory/motor signs), demyelinating plaques on MRI, and variable cognitive impact, but not chorea.
• Misconception: Any neurodegenerative disease causes cognitive decline – MS cognitive changes are mild and subcortical.
• Differentiator: Oligoclonal bands, periventricular lesions, CSF profile.

Comparison Table

FeatureHuntington’s diseaseParkinson’s diseaseWilson’s diseaseMultiple sclerosis
Movement disorderChorea (hyperkinesia)Bradykinesia, rigidity, tremorTremor (wing-beating), dystoniaSpasticity, ataxia
Age of onset30–50 years>60 years10–40 years20–40 years
Genetic/biomarkerHTT CAG repeat >39LRRK2, SNCA mutations (rare)ATP7B mutation, low ceruloplasminHLA-DRB1 association
NeuroimagingCaudate atrophy, ex-vacuole ventriclesNormal initial; DAT scan ↓T2 basal ganglia hyperintensitiesPeriventricular white-matter lesions
TreatmentTetrabenazine, deutetrabenazineLevodopa, DBSChelation (penicillamine), zincImmunomodulators (interferon β)

Clinical Pearls

• Behavioral and psychiatric symptoms often precede chorea by years—screen at-risk individuals.
• Use Unified Huntington’s Disease Rating Scale (UHDRS) for standardized assessment of motor, cognitive, behavioral domains.
• Deutetrabenazine has a longer half-life and lower risk of depression compared to tetrabenazine.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

• Confusing chorea (brief, irregular movements) with tremor or myoclonus leads to diagnostic delay.
• Overlooking psychiatric prodrome—depression or irritability in HD gene carriers may present years before motor signs.
• Assuming all basal ganglia disorders produce chorea; dystonia and parkinsonism have distinct circuit pathology.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• American Academy of Neurology (AAN) Practice Guideline, 2017: Tetrabenazine recommended as first-line for moderate to severe chorea in HD (Level B evidence).
• National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) NG126, 2018: Multidisciplinary management of HD; offer tetrabenazine for chorea; pre- and post-test genetic counseling (Level C).
• First-HD Trial (Huntington Study Group), Lancet Neurology, 2017: Deutetrabenazine significantly reduced chorea score vs placebo (mean change –4.4 vs –1.9; p<0.001); Level I evidence.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Selective degeneration of GABAergic medium spiny neurons in the caudate nucleus and putamen (indirect pathway) leads to disinhibition of thalamocortical circuits, producing chorea. Frontal cortical involvement underlies cognitive and behavioral symptoms.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Expanded polyglutamine tract in mutant huntingtin causes abnormal protein folding, intranuclear inclusions, mitochondrial dysfunction, and excitotoxicity mediated by NMDA receptor overactivation, culminating in neuronal apoptosis.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion: chorea + cognitive/psychiatric changes in adult.
2. Family history assessment.
3. Genetic testing: PCR for CAG repeat length (>39 confirms).
4. Baseline neuropsychological evaluation (UHDRS).
5. MRI to assess caudate atrophy.
6. Multidisciplinary referral (neurology, psychiatry, genetic counseling).

Neuroimaging Pearls

• T1-weighted MRI: caudate head atrophy and putaminal volume loss.
• Ex-vacuole ventriculomegaly (“boxcar” ventricles) from striatal degeneration.
• FDG-PET: hypometabolism in striatum and frontal cortex.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

• Tetrabenazine: VMAT2 inhibitor; start 12.5 mg daily, titrate to 50–75 mg/day in divided doses; monitor for depression, parkinsonism.
• Deutetrabenazine: deuterated form, reduced dosing frequency (6 mg BID up to 48 mg/day); fewer mood side effects.
• Antipsychotics (e.g., olanzapine, risperidone) for chorea and psychosis.
• SSRIs or SNRIs for depression and obsessive symptoms.
• Genetic counseling is essential before testing.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part I 2024 exam.
HD triad (chorea, cognitive decline, behavioral changes) is a classic high-yield topic, tested frequently in neurology sections via clinical vignettes and genetic inheritance questions.

question_text: What is the most common cause of hereditary chorea?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2023] Chorea arises from dysfunction in basal ganglia circuits, particularly loss of indirect‐pathway inhibition in the striatum.
1. Basal ganglia anatomy: medium spiny GABAergic neurons in the caudate/putamen modulate movement via direct (D1) and indirect (D2) pathways through globus pallidus and subthalamic nucleus.
2. Pathophysiology of hereditary chorea: genetic mutations cause progressive neuronal loss in the striatum, reducing inhibitory output and yielding hyperkinetic movements.
3. Inheritance patterns: autosomal dominant disorders (e.g., Huntington disease) predominate among genetic choreas, whereas autosomal recessive (e.g., Wilson) or non‐hereditary causes (e.g., Sydenham) are far less common.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Huntington disease (HD) accounts for over 90% of genetically inherited chorea syndromes. It is autosomal dominant, due to an expanded CAG trinucleotide repeat in HTT on chromosome 4p16.3. Pathologically, mutant huntingtin aggregates lead to selective medium spiny neuron apoptosis in the striatum. Prevalence is ~5–10 per 100,000 in Western populations, vastly exceeding benign hereditary chorea (<1/1,000,000) and other monogenic choreas. The 2018 ACMG guidelines recommend targeted testing for CAG expansion when autosomal dominant chorea is suspected (Grisso et al., 2018). Recent meta‐analyses confirm that >95% of hereditary choreas are attributable to HD (Ross et al., 2020).

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Sydenham chorea
• Why incorrect: Post‐streptococcal autoimmune disorder, not inherited.
• Misconception: acute pediatric chorea is often labeled “hereditary.”
• Differentiator: migratory arthritis, carditis, presentation within weeks of streptococcal pharyngitis.

C. Benign hereditary chorea
• Why incorrect: Rare NKX2-1 mutation (<200 reported families), early‐onset nonprogressive chorea with thyroid/lung involvement.
• Misconception: any “hereditary chorea” equals benign hereditary chorea.
• Differentiator: lack of neurodegeneration and cognitive decline; autosomal dominant with variable penetrance.

D. Wilson disease
• Why incorrect: Autosomal recessive copper‐transport defect; movement disorder is mixed (tremor, dystonia, parkinsonism) rather than pure chorea.
• Misconception: all metabolic causes present with chorea.
• Differentiator: low ceruloplasmin, Kayser–Fleischer rings, hepatic involvement.

Comparison Table

FeatureHuntington DiseaseSydenham ChoreaBenign Hereditary ChoreaWilson Disease
InheritanceADNone (post‐infectious)ADAR
Onset30–50 years5–15 yearsInfancy–childhood5–40 years
ProgressionProgressiveSelf‐limited (months)NonprogressiveProgressive
PathophysiologyCAG expansion → neuronal lossAutoimmune cross‐reactivityNKX2-1 transcription factorCopper accumulation
Key clinical featuresChorea, dementia, psychiatricChorea, emotional labilityPure chorea, hypothyroidismMixed movement (tremor, dystonia, chorea), hepatic signs
Diagnostic testHTT CAG repeat assayASO titers, echo for carditisGenetic testing (NKX2-1)Ceruloplasmin, 24h urinary copper, slit‐lamp

Clinical Pearls

- Presymptomatic CAG repeat testing in at‐risk HD relatives requires thorough genetic counseling per ACMG standards.
• Tetrabenazine (FDA‐approved since 2008) depletes presynaptic monoamines and is first‐line for HD chorea; monitor for depression.
• MRI “bicaudate ratio” >0.16 indicates caudate atrophy in HD and correlates with disease burden.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Equating any chronic chorea with Sydenham chorea; Sydenham’s is acute and post‐streptococcal.
2. Assuming benign hereditary chorea is the most frequent genetic chorea due to its name; in reality HD prevalence is ~100× higher.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. American College of Medical Genetics (ACMG) 2018:
• Recommendation: HTT CAG testing for individuals with adult‐onset chorea and positive FHx.
• Evidence level: B (cohort studies).
2. European Huntington’s Disease Network (EHDN) Consensus 2022:
• Recommendation: Use tetrabenazine as first‐line chorea therapy; consider gene‐lowering trials (e.g., tominersen) in early‐stage patients.
• Evidence level: B (randomized controlled trials, e.g., TETRA‐HD).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

In HD, preferential degeneration of indirect‐pathway medium spiny neurons in the caudate leads to reduced GABAergic inhibition of GPe, decreased STN activation, and thalamic disinhibition manifesting as chorea.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Expanded CAG repeats (>36) in HTT produce polyglutamine aggregates → impaired proteostasis → mitochondrial dysfunction → excitotoxicity via NMDA receptor overactivation → medium spiny neuron apoptosis.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical: progressive chorea + cognitive/psychiatric symptoms + AD family history.
2. Laboratory: exclude metabolic causes (ceruloplasmin, liver enzymes).
3. Neuroimaging: MRI for caudate atrophy.
4. Genetic: confirm HTT CAG repeat number.

Neuroimaging Pearls

Early HD: enlargement of frontal horns of lateral ventricles (“boxcar ventricles”) and caudate head volume loss best seen on T1‐weighted MRI.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Tetrabenazine: start 12.5 mg daily, titrate to 50–75 mg/day; monitor for depression, parkinsonism.
• Deutetrabenazine: longer half‐life, less dosing frequency; similar efficacy.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part I 2023 exam. Hereditary chorea etiologies are frequently tested in multiple‐choice format, often requiring differentiation of HD from metabolic, autoimmune, and benign genetic causes.

question_text: A 61‐year‐old male with a 2‐year history of limb tremors and bradykinesia has postural instability and vertical jaw limitation on exam. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2022] • Atypical parkinsonian syndromes often present with “plus” signs beyond classic bradykinesia, rigidity and tremor.
• Corticobasal degeneration (CBD) is a 4‐repeat tauopathy characterized by asymmetric parkinsonism plus cortical signs (apraxia, myoclonus, orobuccal apraxia).
• Vertical jaw limitation reflects orobuccal apraxia/dystonia in CBD, differentiating it from disorders with predominantly brainstem or autonomic pathology.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Corticobasal degeneration (CBD) is diagnosed when asymmetric limb rigidity/bradykinesia is accompanied by cortical features such as limb or orobuccal apraxia, myoclonus, cortical sensory loss or alien limb phenomenon. Armstrong et al. (Neurology 2013;80:496–503) Movement Disorder Society (MDS) criteria require:
– Asymmetric parkinsonism (rigidity/bradykinesia)
– At least one cortical sign (e.g., orobuccal apraxia causing vertical jaw limitation)
– Poor or transient levodopa response
Neuroimaging often shows asymmetric frontoparietal atrophy (Josephs et al. Brain 2010). In contrast, MSA presents with prominent autonomic failure and cerebellar signs; Alzheimer’s disease lacks parkinsonism; PD shows symmetric progression and robust levodopa responsiveness without cortical apraxia.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Multiple system atrophy (MSA)
– MSA features early autonomic failure (orthostatic hypotension, urinary incontinence) and cerebellar signs; jaw limitation/apraxia is not typical.

C. Alzheimer’s disease (AD)
– AD presents with insidious memory impairment and visuospatial deficits, without bradykinesia, rigidity or postural instability in early stages.

D. Parkinson’s disease (PD)
– PD shows good, sustained levodopa response, rest tremor predominance, symmetry over time, and lacks cortical signs (apraxia).

Comparison Table

FeatureCBDMSAADPD
OnsetAsymmetricSymmetricInsidious memory declineAsymmetric, rest tremor
Levodopa responsePoor/transientPoorN/AGood
Cortical signs+ apraxia, orobuccal, myoclonus–+ memory/visuospatial–
Autonomic failure–+ orthostatic hypotension, urinary–– (late)
MRI findingsAsymmetric frontoparietal atrophy“Hot cross bun” in pons, putaminal lossMedial temporal atrophySubstantia nigra hyperechogenicity

Clinical Pearls

• Orobuccal apraxia (jaw opening/closing difficulty) in the setting of asymmetric parkinsonism is a red flag for CBD.
• A poor or transient response to levodopa therapy distinguishes CBD from idiopathic PD.
• Early postural instability in atypical parkinsonism suggests a “plus” syndrome rather than PD.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Mislabeling vertical gaze palsy as jaw limitation and confusing PSP with CBD—focus on orobuccal rather than ocular findings in CBD.
2. Overinterpreting any tremor as PD; CBD tremor is typically irregular, action‐induced, and asymmetric.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. Armstrong MJ et al. Movement Disorder Society Criteria for CBD, Neurology 2013 (Level III evidence): Defines probable CBD by asymmetric parkinsonism plus ≥1 cortical feature and poor levodopa response.
2. Gilman S et al. Second Consensus Statement on MSA Diagnosis, Neurology 2008 (Level II evidence): Emphasizes autonomic failure and cerebellar signs as core features—absent in CBD.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Degeneration of the contralateral parietal cortex (praxis areas) and basal ganglia underlies the asymmetric motor signs and apraxia in CBD.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

CBD is a tauopathy with accumulation of 4‐repeat tau in neurons and astrocytes, producing astrocytic plaques, neuronal loss, and gliosis predominantly in frontoparietal cortex and basal ganglia.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Confirm parkinsonism (bradykinesia + rigidity/tremor)
2. Assess symmetry and levodopa response
3. Evaluate for cortical signs (apraxia, sensory deficits)
4. Rule out autonomic/cerebellar features
5. Obtain MRI to identify asymmetric cortical atrophy

Neuroimaging Pearls

MRI in CBD typically shows asymmetric atrophy of the primary motor and posterior parietal cortices, often contralateral to the more affected limbs.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Levodopa trials often yield minimal or transient benefit; management focuses on symptomatic relief of dystonia (e.g., botulinum toxin), myoclonus (e.g., clonazepam), and supportive therapies.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part I 2022 exam. Atypical parkinsonian syndromes with cortical “plus” signs are frequently tested, often asking for distinguishing features (e.g., apraxia, asymmetric rigidity, autonomic failure) in a vignette format.

question_text: A patient with Parkinson's disease presents with peak-dose dyskinesia. What medication is commonly used to manage this condition?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2020] Parkinson’s disease (PD) is characterized by nigrostriatal dopamine depletion leading to bradykinesia, rigidity and tremor. Chronic levodopa therapy often produces motor fluctuations: “wearing-off,” “on-off,” and dyskinesias. Peak-dose dyskinesias are involuntary choreiform movements occurring at maximal levodopa plasma levels. Pathophysiologically, pulsatile dopaminergic stimulation causes postsynaptic receptor sensitization and glutamatergic overactivity in the internal globus pallidus and subthalamic nucleus. Management aims to reduce dyskinesias without worsening parkinsonism. Amantadine’s NMDA receptor antagonism modulates glutamate transmission, attenuating hyperkinetic movements. Understanding the basal ganglia circuitry and pharmacodynamics of anti-Parkinsonian drugs is essential for targeted intervention.
(Word count: 127)

Evidence-Based Analysis

Amantadine directly antagonizes NMDA receptors, reducing glutamatergic excitotoxicity implicated in peak-dose dyskinesia (PDS). A randomized, double-blind trial (Katzenschlager et al., 2003, Neurology) demonstrated a 60% reduction in dyskinesia scores versus placebo (p<0.01). The Movement Disorder Society Evidence-Based Review (2019) rates amantadine as Level A efficacy for levodopa-induced dyskinesias. NICE Parkinson’s Guidelines (2022) recommend amantadine (100 mg BID) in patients with troublesome PDS. By contrast, increasing levodopa or using COMT inhibitors exacerbates dyskinesias, while dopamine agonists (e.g., pramipexole) lack robust anti-dyskinetic effects and may provoke impulse control disorders.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Levodopa
– Increases synaptic dopamine and worsens peak-dose dyskinesia.
– Misconception: boosting primary therapy alleviates complications; instead, fractionate dosing.

C. Pramipexole
– Dopamine D2/D3 agonist; helpful for bradykinesia but does not reduce PDS and may induce dyskinesias and impulse control disorders.

D. Entacapone
– COMT inhibitor prolonging levodopa half-life; can amplify peak plasma levels and exacerbate dyskinesias.

Comparison Table

FeatureAmantadineLevodopaPramipexoleEntacapone
MechanismNMDA antagonistDopamine precursorD2/D3 agonistCOMT inhibitor
Effect on PDSReduces by ~50–60%WorsensNeutral/worsensWorsens
Start dosing100 mg BID300 mg TID0.125 mg TID200 mg with each L-dopa
Key side effectsLivedo reticularis, confusionDyskinesia, nauseaSomnolence, impulse controlDiarrhea, dyskinesia

Clinical Pearls

- Initiate amantadine at 100 mg BID; titrate to 300 mg/day to balance efficacy and tolerability.
• Monitor for livedo reticularis and hallucinations, especially in elderly or renal impairment.
• Differentiate peak-dose from diphasic dyskinesia: the latter occurs at low levodopa levels and requires dose adjustments.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Confusing peak-dose dyskinesia with wearing-off: the former occurs at high levodopa levels and responds to amantadine.
• Attempting to reduce PDS by adding COMT inhibitors or increasing levodopa, which worsens the hyperkinetic movements.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. Movement Disorder Society Evidence-Based Review (2019): Amantadine is Level A recommended for levodopa-induced dyskinesias.
2. NICE Parkinson’s Guidelines (2022): Recommends amantadine for troublesome peak-dose dyskinesias (Recommendation 1.2.5).

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Amantadine’s noncompetitive NMDA receptor blockade reduces striatal glutamatergic overactivity. Dosing begins at 100 mg twice daily; adjust for creatinine clearance. Abrupt withdrawal may precipitate akinetic crisis.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 1 2020 exam. Peak-dose dyskinesia management is frequently tested both as a standalone stem and within broader PD motor complication questions. The most commonly tested intervention is amantadine, reflecting its strong evidence base.

question_text: An elderly patient has a history of frequent falls, limited vertical gaze, and parkinsonian features. What is the diagnosis?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2018] Progressive supranuclear palsy (PSP) is a 4‐repeat tauopathy targeting midbrain gaze centers and basal ganglia. Key neuroanatomical structures include the rostral interstitial nucleus of the medial longitudinal fasciculus (riMLF), superior colliculi, and vertical gaze pathways. Clinically, degeneration of these nuclei leads to supranuclear vertical gaze palsy; involvement of the globus pallidus and subthalamic nucleus produces axial rigidity and early postural instability. PSP falls within the spectrum of atypical parkinsonian syndromes, distinguished by poor levodopa response, early falls (within 3 years), and characteristic midbrain atrophy on MRI.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Progressive supranuclear palsy is defined by the Movement Disorder Society (MDS) 2017 criteria: probable PSP requires vertical supranuclear gaze palsy or slowing of vertical saccades plus onset of falls within 3 years (Höglinger et al., Mov Disord 2017). Neuropathologically, accumulation of 4R tau in neurons and glia preferentially affects the midbrain, leading to “hummingbird” sign on sagittal MRI (midbrain atrophy with preserved pons). Clinically, PSP patients exhibit symmetric axial rigidity, early postural instability, and minimal response to levodopa (<30% improvement) (Respondek et al., Brain 2014). No disease‐modifying therapies are approved; management focuses on symptomatic support and rehabilitation.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Multiple system atrophy (MSA)
MSA is an α-synucleinopathy marked by prominent autonomic failure (orthostatic hypotension, urinary retention) and either cerebellar (MSA-C) or parkinsonian (MSA-P) features. Vertical gaze is preserved; cerebellar signs and rapid autonomic decline distinguish MSA from PSP.

C. Parkinson’s disease
Classic PD presents with asymmetric resting tremor, bradykinesia, rigidity, good levodopa response (>50%), and no early falls or supranuclear gaze palsy. Vertical gaze and early postural instability essentially exclude idiopathic PD.

D. Corticobasal degeneration
CBD is a 4R tauopathy with asymmetric cortical features—apraxia, cortical sensory loss, alien‐limb phenomenon—and focal rigidity. Vertical gaze palsy and early falls are not characteristic of CBD.

Comparison Table

FeaturePSPMSAPDCBD
Early falls (< 3 years)YesNoRareNo
Vertical supranuclear gazePresentAbsentAbsentAbsent
Levodopa responsePoor (< 30%)PoorGood (> 50%)Variable
Pathology4‐repeat tauα‐synuclein (glial cytoplasmic bodies)α‐synuclein (Lewy bodies)4‐repeat tau
MRI signMidbrain atrophy (“hummingbird sign”)Putaminal rim sign, cerebellar atrophyNormal or age‐related changesAsymmetric frontoparietal atrophy

Clinical Pearls

- Early postural instability with backward falls and vertical gaze slowing are virtually pathognomonic for PSP.
• Measure midbrain diameter on mid-sagittal MRI; a diameter < 17 mm or MR Parkinsonism Index > 13.55 has > 90% specificity for PSP.
• PSP Rating Scale (PSPRS) tracks progression; falls and gaze subscores correlate best with disease stage.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Mistaking axial rigidity and early falls in PSP for advanced Parkinson’s disease rather than an atypical parkinsonism.
• Over-reliance on tremor or unilateral onset; PSP often lacks tremor and is symmetric.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. Movement Disorder Society (MDS) Clinical Diagnostic Criteria for PSP, Höglinger et al., 2017.
Recommendation: Probable PSP diagnosed by vertical supranuclear gaze palsy or slowed vertical saccades plus falls within 3 years. Level B evidence.
2. European Academy of Neurology (EAN) Practice Guidelines on Imaging in Parkinsonian Syndromes, 2019.
Recommendation: Use midbrain/pons area ratio and MR Parkinsonism Index for differential diagnosis (Level C evidence).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Degeneration of the riMLF and interstitial nucleus of Cajal disrupts vertical saccade generation. Superior colliculi atrophy compounds gaze slowing. Basal ganglia involvement (globus pallidus, subthalamic nucleus) yields axial rigidity and postural instability.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

PSP is a primary tauopathy with abnormal phosphorylation and aggregation of 4‐repeat tau isoforms in neurons and astrocytes, notably tufted astrocytes, leading to neurodegeneration in midbrain, basal ganglia, and frontal cortex.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical history: falls within 3 years + vertical gaze slowing.
2. Neurologic exam: confirm supranuclear palsy (head thrust test).
3. MRI: measure midbrain atrophy (hummingbird sign), calculate MRPI.
4. Exclude mimics (MSA, CBD, PD).
5. Apply MDS 2017 criteria for probable vs possible PSP.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- Sagittal midbrain atrophy (“hummingbird” or “penguin” sign) is highly specific.
• MR Parkinsonism Index (midbrain/pons area × superior cerebellar peduncle/middle cerebellar peduncle ratio) > 13.55 supports PSP.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Levodopa trial often yields < 30% improvement; discontinue if no benefit.
• Amantadine may transiently improve rigidity and dysphagia.
• Botulinum toxin injections can alleviate blepharospasm and dystonia.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part I 2018 exam. Atypical parkinsonism with early falls and vertical gaze palsy is a high‐yield topic, testing recognition of PSP vs other synucleinopathies and tauopathies on board examinations.

question_text: A 62-year-old male has two episodes of asymmetric tremors in the left arm. What investigation should be done to determine the diagnosis?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2022] Parkinsonian tremor arises from degeneration of nigrostriatal dopaminergic neurons, producing a resting “pill‐rolling” tremor often asymmetric at onset. Key concepts:
• Basal ganglia circuitry: loss of substantia nigra pars compacta dopamine → increased indirect pathway activity → tremor.
• Presynaptic dopamine transporter (DAT) density correlates with nigrostriatal neuron integrity.
• Distinguishing Parkinson’s disease (PD) from essential or drug‐induced tremors can be clinically challenging, especially early on.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Dopamine transporter single‐photon emission computed tomography (DAT‐SPECT; e.g., ^123I‐ioflupane) directly visualizes presynaptic DAT binding. Meta‐analyses (Niccolini et al., 2015) report sensitivity >90% and specificity ~85% for neurodegenerative parkinsonism vs. essential tremor. The 2018 Movement Disorder Society PD diagnostic criteria endorse DAT‐SPECT when clinical examination is inconclusive (Level C). In contrast, generic “dopaminergic imaging” (option A) may refer to F‐DOPA PET, which is less widely available and more costly. MRI (option C) is primarily used to exclude structural mimics (e.g., normal‐pressure hydrocephalus, vascular parkinsonism) but lacks sensitivity for early PD. Electromyography (option D) characterizes tremor frequency/amplitude but does not assess dopaminergic neuron loss.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Dopaminergic imaging
• Incorrect because it is nonspecific: could imply F‐DOPA PET rather than DAT‐SPECT.
• Misconception: all dopamine‐targeted imaging are equally diagnostic.
• Differentiator: DAT‐SPECT specifically quantifies presynaptic transporter density.

C. MRI of the brain
• Incorrect: structural MRI is normal in >90% of early PD; used to rule out secondary causes.
• Misconception: MRI can confirm PD.
• Differentiator: MRI can exclude tumor or infarct but can’t measure functional dopamine loss.

D. Electromyography
• Incorrect: EMG delineates tremor pattern (myoclonus vs. tremor) but not pathophysiology.
• Misconception: tremor analysis alone can establish PD diagnosis.
• Differentiator: EMG cannot visualize nigrostriatal degeneration.

Comparison Table

FeatureDAT‐SPECT (Correct)F‐DOPA PET (Dopaminergic)MRI BrainEMG
Measures presynaptic DATYesIndirect via decarboxylaseNoNo
Diagnostic sensitivity (PD)>90%~85%N/AN/A
Excludes structural causesNoNoYesNo
Availability and costModerate cost, widely usedHigh cost, research centersWidely available, low costWidely available, low cost
Clinical roleConfirms nigrostriatal lossResearch/complex casesRule out mimicsCharacterize tremor mechanics

Clinical Pearls

- DAT‐SPECT should be considered in clinically uncertain parkinsonism (rest tremor, rigidity) when response to levodopa is unclear.
• Asymmetric unilateral tremor in an elderly patient raises suspicion for early PD; DAT‐SPECT helps distinguish from essential tremor.
• Normal DAT‐SPECT virtually excludes degenerative parkinsonism (negative predictive value >95%).

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Relying on routine MRI to “confirm” PD – MRI is normal in early stages and cannot assess dopaminergic function.
2. Assuming any dopamine‐targeted imaging is equivalent – F‐DOPA PET and DAT‐SPECT differ in mechanism, availability, and cost.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- Movement Disorder Society (2018): Recommends DAT‐SPECT when clinical diagnosis of PD is uncertain (Level C).
• American Academy of Neurology (2022): Endorses DAT imaging to differentiate tremor‐dominant parkinsonism from essential tremor in ambiguous presentations (Level B).

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical assessment: resting tremor, bradykinesia, rigidity, response to dopaminergic therapy.
2. Exclude mimics: blood tests, head MRI if structural suspicion.
3. If diagnosis remains uncertain → DAT‐SPECT to confirm presynaptic nigrostriatal deficit.
4. Manage accordingly: initiate levodopa or dopamine agonist based on confirmed PD.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- In PD, DAT‐SPECT shows reduced uptake in the posterior putamen, often asymmetric (more severe contralateral to symptomatic side).
• The “comma‐shaped” striatal pattern in healthy adults becomes “burst” or “periodic dotted” in PD due to loss of putaminal binding.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part I 2022 exam. Functional neuroimaging for parkinsonism is frequently tested—expect scenarios contrasting DAT‐SPECT vs. structural MRI to differentiate essential tremor from PD.

question_text: Regarding enhanced physiological tremor, which statement is correct?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2018] Enhanced physiological tremor (EPT) is an exaggeration of the 8–12 Hz tremor present in all healthy individuals.
• Peripheral oscillator: stretch reflex loops in muscle spindles contribute to mechanical tremor.
• Central oscillator: synchronous discharge in the sensorimotor cortex drives baseline tremor.
• Modulators: sympathetic tone, metabolic factors, and exogenous agents (e.g., caffeine, drugs) alter amplitude.
Understanding EPT requires distinguishing it from pathological tremors (e.g., essential tremor, Parkinsonian tremor) by evaluating frequency, activation condition (postural vs. resting), symmetry, and response to alcohol or β-blockers.

Evidence-Based Analysis

The hallmark of EPT is increased amplitude of a normal postural/action tremor. Evidence shows that nonselective β-blockers (propranolol) attenuate EPT by blocking peripheral β₂ receptors in muscle spindles and reducing central adrenergic drive (Elble RJ et al., Neurology 2006; Movement Disorder Society Tremor Classification, 2018). Alcohol does not improve EPT (unlike essential tremor) because GABAergic modulation is less relevant to the peripheral–central oscillator loops of EPT (Louis ED et al., Lancet Neurol 2005). EPT is symmetric and manifest only during posture or voluntary contraction, not at rest.

In the original Part I 2018 exam key, option B (“Tremor worsens with beta-blockers”) was likely a typographical error reversing the true relationship. The correct pharmacological feature is that EPT improves with β-blockers; thus, none of the printed options accurately describes EPT.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Tremor attenuation with alcohol
– Incorrect: EPT does not respond to small doses of ethanol.
– Misconception: equating EPT with essential tremor.
– Differentiator: alcohol improves GABAergic essential tremor, not peripheral oscillator–driven EPT.

C. It is a resting tremor
– Incorrect: EPT is absent at rest and appears only with posture/action.
– Misconception: conflating with Parkinsonian resting tremor.
– Differentiator: EPT frequency (8–12 Hz) vs. Parkinsonian (4–6 Hz); activation condition differs.

D. It is typically asymmetric
– Incorrect: EPT is usually symmetric in both limbs.
– Misconception: assuming all tremors begin unilaterally.
– Differentiator: asymmetry suggests organic tremor (e.g., early Parkinson’s or Holmes tremor).

Comparison Table

FeatureEnhanced Physiological TremorEssential Tremor
Frequency8–12 Hz4–12 Hz
ActivationPostural/action onlyPostural/action; may involve head/lips
Alcohol responseNoneMarked improvement
β-blocker responseImprovement with nonselective agentsImprovement with propranolol
SymmetryTypically symmetricOften symmetric but can start asymmetric
Onset and courseSituational, transient, non-progressiveInsidious, progressive

Clinical Pearls

- Nonselective β-blockers (e.g., propranolol 20–40 mg BID) reduce EPT amplitude by blocking peripheral β₂ receptors in muscle spindles.
• Hyperadrenergic states (e.g., thyrotoxicosis, anxiety, stimulant use) exaggerate physiologic tremor; treat underlying cause.
• Distinguish EPT from enhanced essential tremor: only essential tremor reliably improves with ethanol ingestion.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Equating postural tremor in anxiety with essential tremor rather than EPT.
2. Over-relying on tremor frequency without assessing activation condition and symmetry.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- Movement Disorder Society Tremor Classification (2018): defines EPT as >8 Hz, postural/action, symmetric, non-progressive.
• American Academy of Neurology Practice Guideline (2018): recommends nonselective β-blockers for symptomatic management of physiologic tremor (Level B evidence).

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part I 2018 exam. Questions on tremor often test activation condition (rest vs. posture), frequency, symmetry, and response to alcohol or β-blockers; ensure clear differentiation between physiologic and essential tremor.

question_text: A 14-year-old girl, medically free, has episodes of jerky movements of the right upper limb followed by dystonia with posturing, which occurs suddenly when she turns while running. There is also a family history of migraine. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2021] Paroxysmal dyskinesias are episodic movement disorders characterized by abnormal involuntary movements—chorea, athetosis, dystonia—triggered by specific stimuli. In paroxysmal kinesigenic dyskinesia (PKD), events are precipitated by sudden voluntary movement, last seconds to a minute, preserve consciousness, and often respond dramatically to low-dose carbamazepine. PKD typically presents in childhood or adolescence (median onset ~7-15 years). A positive family history (often PRRT2 mutations) and comorbid migraine or infantile seizures are common. Differential diagnoses include non-kinesigenic dyskinesia, dystonia, reflex epilepsies, and tic disorders—all distinguished by trigger, duration, EEG findings, and responsiveness to therapy.

Evidence-Based Analysis

The correct answer is Paroxysmal kinesigenic dyskinesia. According to the International Parkinson and Movement Disorder Society (2022) consensus, PKD is defined by kinesigenic triggers, brief duration (<1 min), normal interictal exam, and excellent response to anticonvulsants (level B evidence). PRRT2 gene mutations underlie ~80% of familial cases (Chen et al., Neurology 2011;79:191–6), linking synaptic vesicle regulation to hyperexcitability in basal ganglia circuits. Clinical guidelines (American Academy of Neurology, 2023) recommend carbamazepine 2–10 mg/kg/day as first-line therapy, with >90% of patients achieving ≥90% reduction in attack frequency (Yap et al., JAMA Neurol 2020). The sudden onset upon running, brief dystonic posturing, preserved consciousness, and positive family history of migraine are pathognomonic for PKD, not seen in primary dystonia, focal motor epilepsy, or tic disorders.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Dystonia
· Incorrect because primary dystonia presents with sustained or action-induced posturing without clear paroxysmal, kinesigenic triggers or such brief episodes.
· Misconception: conflating any dystonic posture with dystonia rather than episodic dyskinesia.
· Differentiator: dystonia lacks precipitating sudden movement trigger and does not respond so dramatically to carbamazepine.

C. Epilepsy
· Incorrect: focal motor seizures can produce jerks but often involve EEG changes, possible altered awareness, and postictal confusion.
· Misconception: equating all paroxysmal jerks with seizures.
· Differentiator: PKD events preserve consciousness, have normal EEG, and occur only with movement triggers.

D. Tourette syndrome
· Incorrect: tics are stereotyped, suppressible, brief (<500 ms), often accompanied by premonitory urges and vocalizations.
· Misconception: confusing brief jerky movements with tics.
· Differentiator: tics are suppressible, not consistently triggered by movement, and not dystonic postures.

Comparison Table

FeaturePKDDystoniaFocal Motor EpilepsyTourette Syndrome
TriggerSudden voluntary movementVariable/noneSpontaneous or sensory stimuliStress, excitement, not kinesigenic
DurationSeconds (<1 min)Continuous or task-specificSeconds to a few minutes<1 s per tic; clusters possible
ConsciousnessPreservedPreservedMay be impairedPreserved
EEGNormalNormalOften epileptiform dischargesNormal
Family HistoryPRRT2 mutations; migraine, seizuresPositive in genetic dystoniasVariableOften ADHD/OCD comorbidity
Treatment ResponseCarbamazepine highly effectiveLimited response to anticholinergicsAntiepilepticsBehavioral therapy; antipsychotics

Clinical Pearls

1. PKD is often misdiagnosed as epilepsy; always obtain video-EEG during an episode and correlate with kinesigenic triggers.
2. PRRT2 genetic testing confirms diagnosis in ~80% of familial cases; absence of mutation does not exclude PKD.
3. Low-dose carbamazepine (100–200 mg/day) can eliminate attacks—higher doses risk sedation and leukopenia.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Assuming all paroxysmal jerks are seizures—failure to elicit trigger and check EEG leads to unnecessary ASM use.
2. Attributing episodic dystonia to primary dystonia—missing the kinesigenic nature and treatment implications.
3. Overlooking family history of migraine/infantile seizures as a clue to PRRT2-related disorders.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. International Parkinson and Movement Disorder Society, 2022 consensus: formally classifies PKD under paroxysmal dyskinesias; recommends low-dose sodium channel blockers (level B).
2. American Academy of Neurology, 2023 guideline on movement disorders: endorses carbamazepine or oxcarbazepine as first-line PKD therapy (level C).
3. Chen et al., Neurology 2011;79:191–6: PRRT2 mutation identified in 80% familial PKD, linking synaptic dysfunction to movement paroxysms.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

PKD reflects transient dysfunction in the striato-pallido-thalamic circuits. Mutant PRRT2 alters synaptic vesicle release in the striatum, leading to abnormal thalamocortical discharges only upon sudden motor cortex activation.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

PRRT2 haploinsufficiency disrupts SNAP25-mediated neurotransmitter release, lowering excitation thresholds in basal ganglia networks. Kinesigenic triggers then precipitate brief bursts of choreo-dystonic activity.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. History: paroxysmal, kinesigenic trigger, brief, preserved awareness.
2. Video-EEG during event → exclude epilepsy.
3. Trial of carbamazepine → therapeutic response.
4. Genetic testing for PRRT2 if familial or atypical.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Carbamazepine: start 2 mg/kg/day, titrate to 5–10 mg/kg/day; monitor CBC and LFTs. Alternatives: oxcarbazepine, lamotrigine in refractory cases.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 1 2021 exam. Paroxysmal kinesigenic dyskinesia is a classic high-yield topic on neurology boards, frequently tested as short vignettes emphasizing triggers, duration, and treatment response.

question_text: Q110. Which of the following statements is true regarding symptomatic palatal myoclonus?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2019] Symptomatic palatal myoclonus (formerly palatal tremor) arises from lesions in the dentato-rubral-olivary (Guillain-Mollaret) triangle, producing rhythmic contractions of the levator veli palatini. It is distinct from essential palatal tremor, which is idiopathic, often familial, produces an audible click, and persists during sleep. Key anatomy includes the contralateral dentate nucleus, red nucleus, and inferior olive; disruption leads to hypertrophy and rhythmic firing of the inferior olive. Clinically, patients present with continuous palatal movement, dysphagia, dysarthria, and sometimes ocular myoclonus. Understanding the lesion localization and clinical phenotype underpins diagnosis and management.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Option C is correct: symptomatic palatal myoclonus is almost always secondary to a lesion—commonly ischemic stroke, hemorrhage, demyelination, tumor, or trauma—in the Guillain-Mollaret triangle. AAN 2023 guidelines recommend brain MRI with high-resolution T2 and susceptibility-weighted sequences to detect inferior olive hypertrophy or signal changes (Level A). Histopathology and serial imaging studies (e.g., Broich et al., Neurology 2021) confirm that trans-synaptic degeneration of the climbing fibers triggers rhythmic olivary activity. Functional MRI and EMG correlate the anatomical lesion with synchronous palatal contractions. No evidence supports idiopathic or familial causes for the symptomatic variant; ear-clicking is restricted to essential forms. Early identification of the underlying lesion allows targeted therapy—botulinum toxin into the levator veli palatini—with class I/II evidence for symptomatic relief.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. It often disappears with sleep.
• False: both symptomatic and essential palatal tremors typically persist during all sleep stages.
• Misconception: conflating palatal tremor with cortical myoclonus, which may abate in slow-wave sleep.

B. It is idiopathic with or without a family history.
• False: idiopathic/familial patterns describe essential palatal tremor, not the symptomatic form.
• Differentiator: imaging in symptomatic cases reveals lesions; essential cases have normal neuroimaging.

D. It is characterized by an ear-clicking sound.
• False: ear-clicking arises from contraction of the tensor veli palatini in essential tremor.
• Key difference: symptomatic tremor involves levator veli palatini without audible clicks.

Comparison Table

FeatureSymptomatic Palatal MyoclonusEssential Palatal Tremor
EtiologyLesion in Guillain-Mollaret triangle (e.g., stroke)Idiopathic/familial, no lesion
NeuroimagingMRI: inferior olive hypertrophy, T2 hyperintensityNormal structural MRI
Ear-clicking soundAbsentPresent (tensor veli palatini)
Persistence during sleepPersistsPersists

Clinical Pearls

- Symptomatic palatal myoclonus often coexists with oculopalatal tremor; ask about oscillopsia.
• Botulinum toxin A injection into the levator veli palatini yields durable relief; start at 2.5–5 U per side.
• MRI should include dedicated brainstem sequences to detect subtle hypertrophic olivary degeneration.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Assuming palatal tremor that clicks must be symptomatic: clicking is a hallmark of essential form.
2. Believing palatal myoclonus abates during sleep; unlike cortical myoclonus, it continues unabated.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- American Academy of Neurology (AAN) Practice Guideline Update 2023: Recommends high-resolution MRI for all suspected symptomatic palatal myoclonus to identify dentato-rubral-olivary lesions (Level A).
• International Parkinson and Movement Disorder Society (MDS) Evidence Review 2021: Endorses botulinum toxin type A injections into palatal muscles for symptomatic relief of palatal tremor (Recommendation Level B).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Lesions in the contralateral dentate nucleus interrupt inhibitory projections to the red nucleus; trans-synaptic changes in the inferior olive lead to hypertrophy and rhythmic discharges transmitted via the central tegmental tract to the soft palate.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Trans-synaptic degeneration of inferior olive neurons causes aberrant oscillatory activity. Hypertrophic olivary degeneration is not atrophy but enlargement due to vacuolation and gliosis, driving synchronized rhythmic contractions.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical exam: observe palatal movement, test for ear-clicking.
2. Otoscopy: rule out middle ear pathology.
3. Brain MRI: T2/SWI sequences for inferior olive changes.
4. EMG: confirm 1–3 Hz rhythmic palatal muscle discharges.
5. Evaluate for associated ocular or brainstem signs.

Neuroimaging Pearls

Hypertrophic olivary degeneration appears as T2-hyperintense, enlarged inferior olive without contrast enhancement; may evolve weeks to months post-lesion.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

First-line symptomatic therapy is botulinum toxin A (2.5–5 U per injection into levator veli palatini), repeated every 3–4 months. Oral agents (e.g., clonazepam) have limited efficacy.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part I 2019 exam. Questions on palatal myoclonus often test the Guillain-Mollaret triangle anatomy, imaging findings of hypertrophic olivary degeneration, and distinction between essential versus symptomatic tremor. It recurs yearly in neurology board-style vignettes.

question_text: Q107. A patient who works as a chef has been complaining of a months-long history of upper limb resting tremor and rigidity. During the examination, he was found to have unilateral bradykinesia and resting tremor. The patient also mentioned he has a gambling problem. What will you do?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2018] Parkinson’s disease (PD) arises from progressive loss of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra pars compacta, leading to imbalance in basal ganglia motor circuits. Reduced nigrostriatal dopamine impairs the direct pathway (striatum→GPi inhibition) and overactivates the indirect pathway (subthalamic nucleus excitation of GPi), producing resting tremor, rigidity, and bradykinesia—often asymmetrically at onset. Dopaminergic therapies aim to restore striatal dopamine. In contrast, impulse control disorders (ICDs) like pathological gambling result from overstimulation of mesolimbic D3 receptors by dopamine agonists. Therefore, selection of initial therapy must weigh motor efficacy against ICD risk, especially in patients with pre-existing compulsive behaviors.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Carbidopa/levodopa is the most effective symptomatic treatment for PD (AAN 2020 Guidelines, Level A), providing rapid and robust motor improvement. The 2018 Movement Disorder Society–European Academy of Neurology (MDS–EAN) guidelines recommend levodopa as first-line in patients over 60 or those with comorbidities (e.g., existing ICD) due to a lower propensity to induce ICDs compared with dopamine agonists (Level B evidence). Dopamine agonists such as pramipexole and ropinirole carry a 10–15% ICD incidence (Weintraub et al., 2010) by preferential D3 receptor stimulation in the mesolimbic pathway. Entacapone, a COMT inhibitor, is indicated only after motor fluctuations (“wearing‐off”) emerge, not at initial diagnosis. Non-pharmacological therapy alone fails to adequately correct dopaminergic deficiency. Thus, initiating carbidopa/levodopa optimizes motor control while minimizing further ICD risk.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Carbidopa/levodopa/entacapone
• Why incorrect: Entacapone extends levodopa’s half-life and is reserved for patients with established motor fluctuations, not at PD onset.
• Misconception: Early addition of COMT inhibitors enhances initial control; in reality, it increases peak dopamine levels and may worsen ICDs.
• Differentiator: Levodopa monotherapy suffices initially; entacapone is a later adjunct.

C. Dopamine antagonist
• Why incorrect: Antagonists (e.g., haloperidol) block D2 receptors and exacerbate parkinsonism; atypical antipsychotics are used for PD-related psychosis, not motor symptom control.
• Misconception: “Antidopaminergic” drugs can counterbalance PD tremor; they actually worsen bradykinesia and rigidity.
• Differentiator: Correct therapy replaces dopamine, whereas antagonists remove it.

D. Initiate non-pharmacological therapy and monitor symptoms
• Why incorrect: Exercise and physical therapy are beneficial adjuncts but insufficient as sole treatment in symptomatic PD.
• Misconception: Early PD can be managed conservatively without drugs; untreated bradykinesia and rigidity lead to functional decline.
• Differentiator: Pharmacotherapy is indicated when motor signs impair daily activities.

Comparison Table

OptionMechanismIndicationICD RiskMotor Efficacy
Carbidopa/levodopa [CORRECT]Dopamine precursor + peripheral decarboxylase inhibitorFirst-line symptomatic PDLowHigh
Carbidopa/levodopa/entacaponeAbove + COMT inhibitionMotor fluctuations (“wearing-off”)ModerateHigh
Dopamine antagonistD2 receptor blockadePsychosis in PD (not motor therapy)N/AWorsens
Non-pharmacological therapyExercise, diet, physiotherapyAdjunctive onlyNoneNone

Clinical Pearls

- Dopamine agonists preferentially activate D3 receptors in the mesolimbic system, driving ICDs; reserve them for younger patients without compulsive behaviors.
• Levodopa is preferred first-line in patients >60 or with ICD risk; motor fluctuations are managed later with COMT/MAO-B inhibitors or deep brain stimulation.
• Regularly screen for ICDs (gambling, hypersexuality, binge eating) in all patients on dopaminergic therapy, especially agonists.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Mistaking dopamine antagonists for antiparkinsonian agents—instead, they exacerbate motor symptoms.
2. Delaying pharmacotherapy in symptomatic PD underestimating the impact on quality of life and functional capacity.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- Movement Disorder Society–EAN (2018): Recommends levodopa as initial therapy in PD patients >60 or with comorbidities to reduce ICD risk (Level B).
• American Academy of Neurology (2020): Gives levodopa a Grade A endorsement for symptomatic control; advises caution with dopamine agonists in patients predisposed to ICDs.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Degeneration of substantia nigra pars compacta dopaminergic neurons → reduced striatal dopamine → impaired direct (facilitatory) pathway and overactive indirect (inhibitory) pathway → bradykinesia, rigidity. Mesolimbic pathway (ventral tegmental area to nucleus accumbens) mediates reward; overstimulation causes ICDs.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Loss of presynaptic dopamine decreases D1-mediated excitatory input to the direct pathway and removes inhibitory D2 tone from the indirect pathway, resulting in net increased GPi output and motor suppression. Exogenous dopamine agonists can overshoot mesolimbic receptors, altering reward circuitry.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. History: asymmetric resting tremor, rigidity, bradykinesia
2. Exam: confirm cardinal signs, exclude red flags (rapid progression, autonomic failure)
3. Response to levodopa trial: marked motor improvement supports idiopathic PD
4. DaTscan if diagnosis uncertain; MRI to rule out atypical parkinsonism

Neuroimaging Pearls

DaT SPECT demonstrates reduced striatal uptake bilaterally in PD, distinguishing it from essential tremor. MRI is typically normal but useful to exclude structural lesions and atypical syndromes.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Levodopa: start at 300–600 mg/day in divided doses; titrate to balance efficacy vs. dyskinesia.
• Carbidopa 75–100 mg/day prevents peripheral conversion and reduces nausea and orthostatic hypotension.
• Monitor for motor complications; add COMT inhibitors (entacapone) or MAO-B inhibitors (rasagiline) only when fluctuations or dyskinesias develop.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part I 2018 exam. Exam items frequently test selection of Parkinson’s therapies based on age, symptom severity, and risk factors for impulse control disorders.

question_text: Q112. Which of the following Parkinsonian disorders commonly presents with asymmetrical features?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2023] Parkinsonian syndromes are divided into “typical” (idiopathic Parkinson’s disease) and “atypical” (MSA, PSP, CBD) forms. They differ in symmetry of onset, response to levodopa, and accompanying signs. Symmetry refers to equal involvement of both sides in bradykinesia, rigidity or other motor signs. Corticobasal degeneration (CBD) is characterized by markedly asymmetric parkinsonism with cortical dysfunction (apraxia, cortical sensory loss). In contrast, multiple system atrophy (MSA) and progressive supranuclear palsy (PSP) typically present symmetrically, with early autonomic or ocular and postural deficits.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Corticobasal degeneration is a 4‐repeat tauopathy causing focal, unilateral degeneration of the cortex and basal ganglia. The 2013 Movement Disorder Society (MDS) diagnostic criteria for CBD (Armstrong et al.) list asymmetry of motor and cortical signs as a core requirement (Level II evidence). Neuroimaging (Josephs et al., 2006) shows asymmetric frontoparietal and striatal atrophy correlating with the clinically worse side. By contrast, MSA (Gilman et al., 2008 consensus) exhibits symmetric striatonigral or olivopontocerebellar degeneration and early autonomic failure, while PSP (Höglinger et al., 2017 MDS criteria) is marked by symmetric axial rigidity, vertical gaze palsy and early falls. Although idiopathic Parkinson’s disease can be asymmetric, it is not an “atypical” parkinsonism and features a sustained levodopa response and lack of cortical signs.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. MSA: Presents with symmetric parkinsonism, cerebellar signs and autonomic failure. Misconception: equating MSA-P subtype with unilateral PD-like onset.
B. PSP: Displays symmetric axial rigidity, early postural instability and vertical gaze palsy without cortical sensory or apraxic features. Misconception: overlooking the hallmark ocular findings.
D. Parkinson’s disease: Classic PD is asymmetric but distinguished by robust levodopa responsiveness and absence of cortical dysfunction; not classified among atypical parkinsonisms for this question’s context.

Comparison Table

DisorderSymmetryKey Clinical FeaturesImaging Hallmark
CBDMarkedly asymmetricLimb apraxia, cortical sensory loss, dystoniaUnilateral frontoparietal atrophy on MRI
MSASymmetricAutonomic failure, cerebellar signs‘Hot‐cross bun’ sign in pons
PSPSymmetricVertical gaze palsy, early fallsMidbrain atrophy (“hummingbird”)
PDAsymmetricRest tremor, sustained levodopa responseSubtle substantia nigra changes

Clinical Pearls

- Alien limb phenomenon and asymmetric apraxia strongly suggest CBD.
• An early, sustained response to levodopa virtually excludes atypical parkinsonism.
• Asymmetric cortical signs (agraphesthesia, apraxia) are red flags for a tauopathy rather than synucleinopathy.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Attributing any asymmetry to PD and neglecting CBD’s cortical signs.
2. Overlooking eye movement or autonomic features that differentiate PSP and MSA from CBD.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- Armstrong et al., MDS Consensus Criteria for CBD (2013): Asymmetry and cortical dysfunction required for probable CBD (Level II).
• Höglinger et al., MDS Criteria for PSP (2017): Emphasizes symmetric axial rigidity and supranuclear gaze palsy (Level II).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

In CBD, tau deposition targets the postcentral gyrus, supplementary motor area and caudate nucleus on one side, causing asymmetric motor and sensory deficits.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

CBD is characterized by 4‐repeat tau accumulation in neurons and glia, leading to focal cortical and basal ganglia degeneration; MSA and PD are synucleinopathies, and PSP is a 4‐repeat tauopathy with different distribution.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- CBD: Asymmetric frontoparietal and basal ganglia atrophy on MRI; corresponding hypometabolism on FDG‐PET.
• MSA: ‘Hot‐cross bun’ sign in pons on T2‐weighted MRI.
• PSP: Midbrain atrophy producing the “hummingbird” silhouette on sagittal MRI.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part I 2023 exam. Boards frequently test the symmetry of parkinsonian syndromes, particularly the unilateral cortical manifestations of CBD versus symmetric features in MSA and PSP.

question_text: A 50-year-old male came with a history suggestive of Parkinson’s disease (rigidity, tremors, bradykinesia). What is the next step in management?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2021] Parkinson’s disease arises from degeneration of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra pars compacta, leading to dopamine deficiency in the dorsal striatum. Cardinal motor signs—bradykinesia, rigidity, resting tremor—are due to imbalance in direct (facilitatory) and indirect (inhibitory) basal ganglia pathways. Diagnosis is clinical; imaging (DaT-SPECT or PET) is reserved for unclear cases. Symptomatic therapy aims to restore dopaminergic tone, with levodopa/​carbidopa providing the most robust motor improvement. Carbidopa inhibits peripheral decarboxylation of levodopa, increasing CNS availability and reducing nausea/orthostatic hypotension.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Levodopa/​carbidopa is the gold standard for moderate-to-severe Parkinson’s. The PD MED trial (BMJ 2014; n = 1,613) showed early levodopa led to superior long-term quality-of-life (p < 0.01) versus dopamine agonist or MAO-B inhibitor monotherapy. Movement Disorder Society guidelines (2018) assign a Level A recommendation to levodopa for symptomatic control in patients with motor impairment affecting daily activities. Carbidopa (25 mg per dose) prevents peripheral conversion, minimizing GI side effects (Katzenschlager et al., Ann Neurol 2002). Entacapone, a COMT inhibitor, is indicated only after end-of-dose “wearing-off” emerges. Routine PET or DaTscan is not required when clinical criteria are met. Dopamine agonists (e.g., pramipexole) are less potent, carry higher impulse control disorder risk (Level B), and are reserved for mild symptoms in younger patients aiming to delay dyskinesias.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Levodopa/Carbidopa/Entacapone
• Why incorrect: COMT inhibitors like entacapone are added to manage motor fluctuations (wearing-off), not at initial diagnosis.
• Misconception: Belief that upfront COMT inhibition improves long-term motor control.
• Differentiator: Entacapone’s benefit emerges only after levodopa plasma peaks become erratic.

C. PET Scan
• Why incorrect: Metabolic imaging (e.g., FDOPA PET) or DaT-SPECT confirms nigrostriatal loss but is unnecessary in a patient with classic signs.
• Misconception: Assuming imaging is mandatory for diagnosis.
• Differentiator: Clinical diagnostic criteria (UK Brain Bank) suffice; imaging is second-line.

D. Dopamine agonists
• Why incorrect: Though agonists can delay levodopa-induced dyskinesias in patients <60 with mild symptoms, they provide inferior symptom control and higher rates of impulse control disorders.
• Misconception: Younger age universally mandates agonist monotherapy.
• Differentiator: Levodopa’s superior efficacy outweighs dyskinesia risk when daily function is impaired.

Comparison Table

FeatureLevodopa/CarbidopaLevodopa/Carbidopa/EntacaponePET ScanDopamine Agonists
MechanismDopamine precursor + decarboxylase inhibitor+ COMT inhibitionNeuroimaging tracer uptakeD2/D3 receptor agonism
IndicationFirst-line symptomatic therapySecondary: wearing-off managementDiagnostic uncertaintyMild PD in <60 years
EfficacyHighest motor improvementSame as levodopa once stableN/AModerate
Onset of ActionRapid (hours)Rapid (with levodopa)Diagnostic delaySlower than levodopa
Key RisksDyskinesias, motor fluctuationsAs levodopa + diarrhea, hepatotoxicity riskRadiation exposureImpulse control disorders

Clinical Pearls

- Always pair levodopa with ≥25 mg carbidopa to reduce peripheral side effects.
• Initiate at 100 mg/25 mg TID and titrate weekly by 100 mg levodopa increments to minimize dyskinesias.
• Monitor for wear-off; add entacapone (200 mg) only when end-of-dose motor fluctuations develop.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Ordering DaT-SPECT or PET in classic presentations, which rarely alters management.
2. Starting COMT inhibitors de novo, increasing pill burden without benefit.
3. Preferring dopamine agonists in younger patients regardless of symptom severity.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- Movement Disorder Society (MDS) Evidence-based Review, 2018: Level A recommendation for levodopa/carbidopa in moderate-to-severe PD; dopamine agonists Level B for delaying dyskinesias in mild PD.
• NICE Guideline CG35, 2017: Recommends levodopa for patients ≥65 years; consider dopamine agonists or MAO-B inhibitors in <65 years with mild symptoms.
• PD MED Trial, BMJ 2014: Early levodopa was superior to dopamine agonist/MAO-B inhibitor monotherapy in long-term mobility and quality of life.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Degeneration of nigrostriatal dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra pars compacta reduces dopamine in the caudate and putamen, disrupting direct (D1-mediated) and indirect (D2-mediated) basal ganglia pathways and leading to bradykinesia and rigidity.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Misfolded α-synuclein forms Lewy bodies, triggering neuronal apoptosis in the SNpc; symptom onset occurs after 60–80% neuronal loss, causing striatal dopamine depletion and impaired thalamocortical activation.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical assessment: Confirm bradykinesia + rigidity or rest tremor.
2. Exclude “red flags” (e.g., rapid progression, early autonomic failure).
3. Optional imaging (DaT-SPECT) if diagnosis remains uncertain.
4. Initiate symptomatic therapy based on severity, age, and lifestyle.

Neuroimaging Pearls

DaT-SPECT reveals reduced striatal dopamine transporter binding (especially posterior putamen) in PD; normal in essential tremor, aiding differentiation.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Levodopa/carbidopa mechanism: Levodopa crosses BBB → decarboxylated to dopamine centrally; carbidopa inhibits peripheral DOPA decarboxylase. Start 100 mg/25 mg TID, titrate up; monitor for motor fluctuations and dyskinesias, adding entacapone or MAO-B inhibitors as needed.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 1 2021 exam. Initial Parkinson’s management—especially choosing levodopa vs. dopamine agonist vs. COMT inhibitor—is frequently tested in single-best-answer format, emphasizing age and symptom severity.

question_text: A 14-year-old girl, medically free, has episodes of jerky movements of the right upper limb followed by dystonia with posturing, which occur suddenly when she turns while running. There is also a family history of migraine. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2020] Paroxysmal dyskinesias are episodic hyperkinetic movement disorders mediated by basal ganglia circuit dysfunction.
1. “Kinesigenic” indicates attacks triggered by sudden voluntary movement (e.g., turning, startle) lasting seconds.
2. “Exercise-induced” dyskinesia arises after prolonged exertion (minutes), with attacks usually lasting longer.
3. Genetic forms include PRRT2 mutations (PKD) and TOR1A (DYT1), but DYT1 causes persistent dystonia, not paroxysmal.
4. Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy presents with early-morning myoclonic jerks and generalized spike-wave discharges, not movement-triggered dystonia.
Recognition of precise triggers, duration, and phenomenology is key for accurate classification.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Paroxysmal kinesigenic dyskinesia (PKD) is characterized by brief (seconds–minutes) dystonic or choreoathetoid episodes precipitated by sudden movement or startle. PRRT2 gene mutations underlie ~60% of familial cases, disrupting presynaptic vesicle release and neuronal excitability. First-line therapy with low-dose carbamazepine (100–200 mg/d) yields >90% response (Rock et al., 2014; MDS Evidence-Based Guideline 2017, Level A). Attacks resolve by adolescence in many. Video-EEG studies are normal during episodes, distinguishing PKD from epileptic myoclonus. Family history of migraine is common in PRRT2 mutation carriers, reflecting shared neuronal hyperexcitability pathways (Zhang et al., 2015).

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Paroxysmal exercise-induced dyskinesia
• Triggered by prolonged exertion (e.g., >5 min running), not sudden turns.
• Attacks onset latency of minutes and last longer (5–30 min).
• Responds less robustly to carbamazepine (MDS Guideline 2017, Level C).

C. DYT1
• TOR1A mutation causes early-onset generalized dystonia, persistent rather than episodic.
• No clear movement trigger, often begins in leg/arm and generalizes.

D. Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy
• Presents with bilateral myoclonic jerks, generalized tonic-clonic seizures, and characteristic 4–6 Hz spike-wave on EEG.
• Attacks not precipitated by sudden movement, and dystonia is absent.

Comparison Table

FeaturePKDPEDDYT1JME
TriggerSudden movementProlonged exerciseNone (spontaneous)Sleep deprivation, photic
Attack latency<1 sminutesN/AN/A
DurationSeconds–minutes5–30 minutesContinuousBrief myoclonic jerks
EEGNormal during eventsNormalNormalGeneralized spike-wave
Genetic mutationPRRT2SLC2A1 (often)TOR1AGenetic susceptibility (GABRA1)
TreatmentCarbamazepine (Level A)Levodopa, ketogenic diet (C)Anticholinergics, DBSValproate, levetiracetam

Clinical Pearls

• PRRT2 mutations often co-present with benign familial infantile seizures and migraine.
• A normal ictal EEG during paroxysmal events rules out epileptic myoclonus.
