• Trinucleotide repeat expansions vary by sequence and disease: GAA in FRDA, CAG in polyglutamine disorders, CTG in myotonic dystrophy.
• Frataxin, encoded by FXN on chromosome 9, is essential for mitochondrial iron–sulfur cluster assembly; its deficiency leads to neuronal degeneration.
• Clinical hallmarks include gait and limb ataxia, absent deep-tendon reflexes, Babinski signs, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, and diabetes mellitus.

Evidence-Based Analysis

The correct answer is GAA because FRDA arises from homozygous GAA repeat expansions in intron 1 of the frataxin (FXN) gene. Campuzano et al. (1996) first identified this mutation; typical pathogenic alleles contain 66–1,700 repeats. GAA expansions impede transcription via heterochromatin formation, reducing frataxin levels and causing mitochondrial iron overload, oxidative stress, and apoptotic loss of dorsal root ganglia and spinocerebellar tracts. Clinically, repeat length inversely correlates with age at onset and severity (e.g., >800 repeats → onset <15 years). Diagnosis relies on triplet-primed PCR for alleles ≤1,000 repeats and Southern blot for larger expansions (ACMG/AMP 2023). No other trinucleotide motif produces the FRDA phenotype:
• CAG expansions (e.g., HTT, spinocerebellar ataxias) cause polyglutamine toxicity.
• CTG expansions (DMPK) underlie myotonic dystrophy type 1.
• “CIG” is not a pathogenic repeat in human neurologic disease.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. CIG
• Incorrect: “CIG” is not a biologically recognized trinucleotide repeat; no human disease maps to CIG.
• Misconception: Assuming any three-base sequence could underlie FRDA.
• Differentiator: FRDA specifically involves GAA sequence.

B. CAG
• Incorrect: CAG expansions encode glutamine repeats, causing Huntington’s disease or spinocerebellar ataxia type 1, not FRDA.
• Misconception: Confusing polyglutamine ataxias with FRDA.
• Differentiator: CAG expansions alter coding regions; GAA occurs in an intron.

D. CTG
• Incorrect: CTG expansions in the DMPK gene cause myotonic dystrophy type 1, characterized by myotonia and endocrinopathies, not prototypical spinocerebellar degeneration of FRDA.
• Misconception: Equating any repeat expansion disorder with FRDA.
• Differentiator: CTG repeats produce RNA toxicity and mis-splicing, whereas GAA causes transcriptional silencing of FXN.

Comparison Table

OptionRepeat SequenceAssociated DiseaseGene (Chromosome)Pathogenic Mechanism
A. CIGCIGNone knownN/ANot applicable
B. CAGCAGHuntington’s; SCA1, SCA3…HTT (4q), ATXN1 (6p)…Polyglutamine aggregation
C. GAAGAAFriedreich’s ataxiaFXN (9q21.11)Transcriptional repression
D. CTGCTGMyotonic dystrophy type 1DMPK (19q13.32)RNA-mediated splicing defects

Clinical Pearls

- FRDA often presents with gait ataxia before age 25; always screen for hypertrophic cardiomyopathy and diabetes.
• Frataxin levels can be measured in blood; correlate inversely with GAA repeat length.
• In suspected hereditary ataxia, GAA repeat testing is first-line—muscle biopsy is no longer required.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Confusing GAA expansions with CAG expansions and misattributing FRDA features to polyglutamine disorders.
2. Believing FRDA is autosomal dominant because other ataxias (e.g., SCA1) follow that pattern.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- ACMG/AMP 2023 Joint Consensus: Recommends triplet-primed PCR plus Southern blot for accurate GAA repeat sizing in FRDA; pathogenic threshold ≥66 repeats (Level B).
• U.S. FDA Approval (2023): Omaveloxolone indicated for FRDA based on the pivotal MOXIe trial demonstrating significant improvement in modified FARS scores at 48 weeks (Level I).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Degeneration of dorsal root ganglia, spinocerebellar tracts, posterior columns, and dentate nuclei results in loss of proprioception and cerebellar signaling, producing combined sensory and cerebellar ataxia.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

GAA expansions induce heterochromatin formation around FXN, reducing transcription and frataxin protein. Frataxin deficiency disrupts mitochondrial iron–sulfur cluster assembly, increases reactive oxygen species, and precipitates neuronal apoptosis in spinal cord and cerebellum.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part I 2023 exam. Genetic mechanisms of trinucleotide repeat disorders are a high-yield topic, frequently tested as direct recall of the specific repeat sequence (e.g., GAA in FRDA, CAG in Huntington’s, CTG in myotonic dystrophy).

question_text: A patient with a history of abnormal movements and falls, which interfere with his daily routine, is experiencing behavioral and mood changes. What trinucleotide repeat expansion would you expect to find?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2023] Huntington’s disease (HD) is an autosomal dominant neurodegenerative disorder caused by CAG repeat expansion in the HTT gene. Key concepts:
• Trinucleotide repeat expansions produce toxic gain-of-function proteins; CAG encodes polyglutamine.
• Anticipation: number of repeats often increases in successive generations, especially paternal transmission, correlating with earlier onset.
• Clinical triad: chorea (abnormal involuntary movements), cognitive decline, psychiatric disturbances (depression, irritability).

Evidence-Based Analysis

The HTT gene on chromosome 4p16.3 harbors a CAG repeat: normal ≤26; intermediate 27–35; reduced penetrance 36–39; full penetrance ≥40. Expanded polyglutamine tract induces neuronal dysfunction and apoptosis, predominantly in the striatum and cortex. Walker FO (Lancet 2007) and Ross & Tabrizi (Lancet Neurol 2011) elucidate the pathogenic cascade: mutant huntingtin disrupts transcription, mitochondrial function, and proteostasis. Clinical guidelines (see below) mandate PCR-based CAG sizing for definitive diagnosis and predictive testing.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. CTG
• Mutation in DMPK gene causing myotonic dystrophy type 1
• Represents myotonia, cataracts, cardiac conduction defects, not chorea
• Misconception: CTG expansions cause muscle stiffness, not hyperkinetic movement

C. CGG
• Expansion in FMR1 gene causing Fragile X syndrome
• Presents with intellectual disability, macroorchidism, autism features
• Misconception: any trinucleotide repeat implies neurodegeneration; CGG is developmental

D. GAA
• Expansion in FXN gene causing Friedreich’s ataxia
• Leads to spinocerebellar ataxia, sensory neuropathy, cardiomyopathy
• Misconception: GAA can cause falls, but pathology is cerebellar, not choreiform

Comparison Table

FeatureCAG (HD)CTG (DM1)CGG (Fragile X)GAA (Friedreich’s)
GeneHTT (4p16.3)DMPK (19q13.3)FMR1 (Xq27.3)FXN (9q21.11)
Repeat UnitCAGCTGCGGGAA
Pathogenic Repeat Range≥40≥50≥200>66
Key Clinical FeaturesChorea, cognitive decline, psychiatric changesMyotonia, muscle weakness, cataractsIntellectual disability, autism-like behaviorsGait ataxia, neuropathy, cardiomyopathy

Clinical Pearls

- Paternal transmission often yields greater CAG expansion and earlier onset.
• Predictive testing requires pre- and post-test genetic counseling due to psychosocial impact.
• Tetrabenazine is FDA-approved for chorea in HD; monitor for depression.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Confusing CTG (myotonic dystrophy) with CAG (Huntington’s) due to similar repeat names.
• Overlooking psychiatric symptoms that often precede motor signs in HD.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. American College of Medical Genetics and Genomics (ACMG) & Association for Molecular Pathology (AMP), 2018
• Recommendation: PCR-based CAG sizing with standardized thresholds for normal, intermediate, reduced penetrance, and full penetrance alleles. (Level A)
2. European Huntington’s Disease Network (EHDN) Consensus Guidelines, 2021
• Recommendation: Confirm clinical suspicion with molecular CAG testing and integrate multidisciplinary care; emphasize genetic counseling. (Level B)

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part I 2023 exam.
Huntington’s disease–related trinucleotide repeats are frequently tested on neurology boards, often in the context of genetic anticipation and movement disorder differentials.

question_text: A patient known to have psychiatric symptoms on antipsychotic medication for a long time presented with abnormal movements of the face and tongue. What is the diagnosis?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2018] Chronic dopamine D2‐receptor blockade in the nigrostriatal pathway leads to compensatory receptor upregulation and hypersensitivity, manifesting as tardive syndromes.
Key concepts:
1. Basal ganglia circuits—especially the direct and indirect pathways in the dorsal striatum—modulate movement; imbalance causes hyperkinetic or hypokinetic disorders.
2. Acute vs. tardive antipsychotic‐induced movement disorders differ by latency, phenomenology, and reversibility.
3. Orofacial choreoathetoid movements (tongue protrusion, lip smacking) emerging after months to years of neuroleptic exposure are hallmark for tardive dyskinesia.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Tardive dyskinesia (TD) is best explained by chronic D2 blockade inducing postsynaptic receptor supersensitivity in the nigrostriatal pathway. The 2021 APA Practice Guideline for Schizophrenia recommends systematic AIMS screening and use of vesicular monoamine transporter 2 (VMAT2) inhibitors (valbenazine, deutetrabenazine) for moderate–severe TD (Level B evidence). A 2018 AAN guideline update on tardive syndromes rates valbenazine and deutetrabenazine as Level A for symptomatic improvement (Jankovic et al., Neurology 2018). A Cochrane review (2017) demonstrated a mean 40–50% reduction in AIMS scores with VMAT2 inhibitors vs. placebo (high‐quality RCTs). TD movements are typically persistent, often irreversible without treatment, and distinct from acute dystonia, parkinsonism, or neuroleptic malignant syndrome.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Neuroleptic malignant syndrome
– Incorrect because NMS presents acutely with “lead‐pipe” rigidity, hyperthermia, autonomic instability, elevated CK, leukocytosis.
– Misconception: equating any antipsychotic side‐effect with NMS; NMS is an emergency, not isolated orofacial chorea.
– Differentiator: systemic findings and lab abnormalities vs. purely choreiform movements.

C. Acute dystonic reaction
– Incorrect: acute dystonia manifests within days of antipsychotic initiation as sustained, often painful muscle contractions (e.g., oculogyric crisis, torticollis), not choreoathetoid orofacial movements.
– Misconception: interpreting all involuntary movements as dystonia.
– Differentiator: timing (hours–days), muscle contraction pattern, reversibility with anticholinergics.

D. Parkinsonism
– Incorrect: drug‐induced parkinsonism features bradykinesia, rigidity, resting tremor, postural instability, symmetrical presentation.
– Misconception: labeling any slowed or stiff movement as parkinsonism; fails to note hyperkinetic nature of chorea.
– Differentiator: hypokinetic vs. hyperkinetic phenomenology; absence of bradykinesia in TD.

Comparison Table

FeatureTardive DyskinesiaNMSAcute DystoniaParkinsonism
OnsetMonths–years after neurolepticDays–weeksHours–daysWeeks–months
PhenomenologyChoreoathetoid/orofacial movements“Lead‐pipe” rigidity, feverSustained involuntary posturesBradykinesia, rigidity, tremor
Lab findingsNormal↑CK, leukocytosis, metabolic derangementsNormalNormal
Response to anticholinergicsMinimalNoRapid improvementNo

Clinical Pearls

• Use the Abnormal Involuntary Movement Scale (AIMS) every 6–12 months in patients on antipsychotics.
• VMAT2 inhibitors (valbenazine 40–80 mg daily; deutetrabenazine titrated to 12–48 mg daily) are first‐line pharmacotherapy for TD.
• Reducing or switching antipsychotics may mitigate TD progression—avoid increasing dose in suspected cases.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Over‐diagnosing dystonia when viewing intermittent choreiform movements.
2. Failing to distinguish tardive dyskinesia from spontaneous or hereditary choreas (e.g., Huntington disease) without drug history.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• APA Practice Guideline for the Treatment of Patients With Schizophrenia, 2021:
– Recommendation: Routine AIMS screening; consider VMAT2 inhibitors for moderate–severe TD (Level B).
• AAN Evidence-Based Guideline Update on Tardive Syndromes, 2018:
– Recommendation: Valbenazine and deutetrabenazine are effective for TD symptom reduction (Level A).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

TD arises from dysfunction in the nigrostriatal pathway: chronic D2 blockade alters GABAergic output from the striatum to the globus pallidus and substantia nigra, disrupting thalamo‐cortical modulation and producing hyperkinetic movements.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Chronic dopamine antagonism → postsynaptic D2 receptor upregulation and hypersensitivity → aberrant synaptic plasticity, oxidative stress, GABAergic interneuron loss → involuntary choreiform movements.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Confirm history of ≥3 months neuroleptic exposure.
2. Characterize movement type (chorea vs dystonia vs tremor).
3. Exclude other causes (metabolic, genetic).
4. Grade severity with AIMS.
5. Initiate VMAT2 inhibitor if moderate–severe.

Neuroimaging Pearls

Neuroimaging (MRI/CT) is typically normal; used only to exclude other structural or metabolic etiologies in atypical presentations.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

First‐line: VMAT2 inhibitors—valbenazine (initial 40 mg QD, increase to 80 mg), deutetrabenazine (titrate from 12 mg to 48 mg divided BID). Monitor for depression, QT prolongation.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part I 2018 exam.
Tardive dyskinesia is frequently tested in the context of antipsychotic side effects, often as vignette‐based questions contrasting acute vs tardive syndromes.

question_text: A patient with Parkinson's disease presents with hallucinations and forgetfulness. What is the most appropriate management option?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2024] Parkinson’s disease (PD) is defined by nigrostriatal dopaminergic neuron loss in the substantia nigra pars compacta, causing classic motor signs. Non-motor features—visual hallucinations and dementia—stem from cortical Lewy body deposition, mesolimbic dopaminergic hyperactivity, and basal forebrain cholinergic deficits. Psychosis in PD requires agents that antagonize 5-HT2A or D2 receptors without exacerbating parkinsonism. Cognitive decline in Parkinson’s disease dementia (PDD) reflects cholinergic loss, treatable with acetylcholinesterase inhibitors. Balancing these pathways guides targeted therapy: antipsychotics for hallucinations and cholinesterase inhibitors for memory.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Clozapine is supported by Level A evidence in the Movement Disorder Society (MDS) evidence-based review (Seppi et al., 2011; updated 2017) for PD psychosis. Two double-blind RCTs (Aarsland et al., 2005; Ondo et al., 2011) demonstrated a 60–80% reduction in hallucination frequency over 6–8 weeks without motor deterioration (D2 occupancy < 60%; potent 5-HT2A antagonism). Rivastigmine (Emre et al., 2004) improved MMSE by ~2 points over 24 weeks (Level B evidence) and mildly reduced Neuropsychiatric Inventory hallucination scores, but lacks primary antipsychotic efficacy. Levodopa intensification aggravates mesolimbic dopamine–mediated psychosis. Amantadine’s NMDA antagonism may precipitate or worsen hallucinations. Therefore, in combined PDP psychosis and dementia, clozapine is the most evidence-based choice.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Rivastigmine
– Targets cholinergic deficits in PDD; improves cognition but has minimal direct antipsychotic effect.
– Misconception: assuming cognitive enhancers resolve psychotic symptoms.
– Does not antagonize mesolimbic dopamine overactivity that underlies hallucinations.

C. Levodopa
– Dopamine precursor for motor symptom relief.
– Worsens psychosis by increasing mesolimbic dopamine.
– Common error: conflating motor improvement with non-motor symptom control.

D. Amantadine
– NMDA receptor antagonist used for levodopa-induced dyskinesias.
– Can provoke or exacerbate hallucinations via anticholinergic side effects.
– Mistakenly believed to have broad neuropsychiatric benefits, but contraindicated in active psychosis.

Comparison Table

FeatureClozapineRivastigmineLevodopaAmantadine
MechanismD2/5-HT2A antagonismAcetylcholinesterase inhibitionDopamine precursorNMDA receptor antagonism
Primary PD IndicationPsychosisDementia (PDD)Motor symptomsDyskinesias
Effect on Hallucinations↓ Significant (Level A evidence)↓ Minimal↑ Exacerbates↑ Exacerbates
Motor ImpactNeutralNeutralImprovesImproves
Key Adverse EffectsAgranulocytosis (monitor CBC)Nausea, vomitingDyskinesias, psychosisHallucinations, peripheral edema

Clinical Pearls

– Initiate clozapine at 12.5 mg nightly and titrate to 25–50 mg/day; monitor CBC weekly for 6 months, then biweekly.
– Pimavanserin, a 5-HT2A inverse agonist, is an FDA-approved alternative for PDP without motor worsening.
– Always attempt reduction of dopaminergic therapy before adding antipsychotics in PD psychosis.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Prescribing risperidone or haloperidol for PDP—high D2 blockade worsens parkinsonism.
2. Assuming cholinesterase inhibitors (e.g., rivastigmine) sufficiently treat visual hallucinations.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

– Movement Disorder Society Task Force on PDP (Seppi et al., 2011; updated 2017):
• Clozapine – Level A recommendation for PD psychosis.
• Rivastigmine – Level B for PDD cognition; minimal psychosis benefit.
– NICE Guideline NG72 (2017, updated 2022):
• First reduce dopaminergic meds; then consider clozapine in specialist centers.
• Use rivastigmine transdermal for PDD cognitive symptoms (Evidence level 1+).
– Pimavanserin Phase III trial (ACP-103, 2014): 37% improvement in SAPS-PD vs placebo; no motor effect.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Psychosis arises from mesolimbic pathway overactivity (ventral tegmental area to nucleus accumbens) and frontal cortex 5-HT2A receptor dysregulation. Dementia involves degeneration of cholinergic neurons in the nucleus basalis of Meynert projecting to cortex.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

α-Synuclein aggregates in cortical and limbic regions disrupt cholinergic and serotonergic circuits, while exogenous dopaminergic therapy further disinhibits mesolimbic dopamine release, precipitating psychosis.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Clozapine: start low (12.5 mg), slow titration, strict hematologic monitoring due to agranulocytosis risk. Avoid anticholinergics which can worsen cognitive decline.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part I 2024 exam. Questions on PD non-motor management frequently test the selection of antipsychotics with minimal motor impact and the role of cholinesterase inhibitors in dementia.

question_text: A patient presents with blunted affect and rigidity after carbon monoxide exposure. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2022] - Carbon monoxide binds hemoglobin with high affinity, causing tissue hypoxia; the globus pallidus is especially vulnerable to hypoxic–ischemic injury.
• Basal ganglia circuits (globus pallidus, putamen, substantia nigra) regulate movement and facial expression; damage produces the cardinal features of parkinsonism: rigidity, bradykinesia, and “masked” facies (blunted affect).
• Delayed post-hypoxic parkinsonism typically emerges days to weeks after CO exposure, distinguishing it from acute toxic or metabolic encephalopathies.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Option D, neuroleptic malignant syndrome (NMS), is characterized by acute onset “lead-pipe” rigidity, altered mental status (which may include mutism or blunted affect), autonomic instability, fever, and elevated creatine kinase, all in the setting of recent dopamine-blocking agent exposure. Although rigidity and affective flattening overlap with this patient’s presentation, NMS cannot occur without antecedent neuroleptic use and core features of hyperthermia and autonomic lability—none of which are described.
By contrast, moderate to severe CO poisoning results in delayed bilateral globus pallidus necrosis. Patients develop parkinsonian rigidity and masked facies 1–3 weeks post-exposure. MRI T2 images demonstrate symmetric pallidal hyperintensities (Rose et al., 2018). In cohort studies, 20–40% of survivors of moderate CO exposure manifest delayed parkinsonism (Yen et al., 2014). Thus, although the 2022 Part I exam key lists NMS, the true diagnosis is carbon monoxide–induced parkinsonism—unfortunately not offered among the choices.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Depression
• Depression produces blunted affect but not sustained extrapyramidal rigidity. Psychomotor retardation may slow movement but lacks cogwheel or lead-pipe rigidity.

B. Recurrent seizures
• Seizures present with transient motor phenomena and postictal confusion, not persistent rigidity or affect flattening.

C. Subclinical status epilepticus
• Would be confirmed by continuous epileptiform discharges on EEG and show intermittent twitches or subtle automatisms, not sustained extrapyramidal signs.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part I 2022 exam. Boards frequently test delayed neurologic sequelae of hypoxic insults—particularly CO-induced parkinsonism with rigidity and masked facies—so be wary of answer choices that describe drug-induced syndromes (e.g., NMS) rather than toxin-mediated basal ganglia injury.

question_text: A Parkinson’s patient on medication develops wearing-off phenomena. What is the mechanism?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2021] Parkinson’s disease (PD) arises from progressive degeneration of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra pars compacta (SNpc). Levodopa remains the most efficacious symptomatic treatment, converted to dopamine in surviving terminals.
• Early in PD, intact terminals buffer pulsatile plasma levodopa, sustaining continuous dopamine release.
• As SNpc cell loss advances, buffering capacity wanes, the therapeutic window narrows, and patients experience “wearing-off”—return of parkinsonian signs before the next dose.
• Recognizing motor fluctuations (wearing-off vs. on-off phenomenon vs. dyskinesias) is critical for tailoring therapy.
(≈100 words)

Evidence-Based Analysis

Wearing-off reflects disease progression leading to loss of presynaptic dopamine storage vesicles and diminished capacity to buffer levodopa’s short half-life (1.5–2 h). The concept of continuous dopaminergic stimulation (CDS), introduced by Nutt et al (2001), posits that pulsatile receptor stimulation accelerates motor complications. A meta-analysis (Olanow et al, 2013) confirmed that as nigrostriatal degeneration reaches ~70 %, the amplitude of striatal dopamine falls below threshold, causing predictable end-of-dose failure. Current MDS-Evidence Based Medicine Review (Espay et al, 2020) designates disease progression as the principal driver (Level A evidence). Management strategies focus on restoring CDS via dose fractionation, COMT inhibitors (e.g., entacapone), MAO-B inhibitors (e.g., rasagiline), or continuous infusion therapies.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Failure of medication
• Why incorrect: Levodopa retains efficacy; “failure” suggests primary non-response, not fluctuation.
• Misconception: Equating wearing-off with loss of drug potency.
• Differentiator: True medication failure is rare; wearing-off is time-dependent return of symptoms.

C. Medication intolerance
• Why incorrect: Intolerance refers to adverse side effects (e.g., nausea, hypotension), not reemergence of parkinsonism.
• Misconception: Attributing motor fluctuations to side-effect profiles.
• Differentiator: Intolerance causes discontinuation or dose reduction, not predictable off periods.

D. Altered pharmacokinetics of levodopa
• Why incorrect: While levodopa’s short half-life contributes to fluctuations, primary driver is loss of neuronal storage rather than peripheral absorption changes.
• Misconception: Blaming GI motility or protein interactions as sole cause.
• Differentiator: Pharmacokinetic factors modulate wearing-off severity but do not explain loss of buffering capacity.

Comparison Table

FeatureDisease Progression (B)Failure of Med (A)Med Intolerance (C)Altered PK (D)
Underlying pathologyNigrostriatal neuron lossDrug inefficacyAdverse reactionsChanges in absorption/metabolism
Clinical presentationPredictable end-of-dose off timeNo initial response or benefit lostGI, CV, psychiatric effectsVariable onset, not time-locked
Therapeutic intervention focusCDS: dose fractionation, adjunctsSwitch therapy or trial alternativeManage side effectsModify dosing relative to meals
Evidence baseMDS 2020 Level ARare, anecdotalPharmacovigilance dataSupplemental, lower level evidence

Clinical Pearls

1. ~50 % of patients develop wearing-off within 5 years of levodopa therapy; <10 % show it at 1 year (Ahlskog & Muenter, 2001).
2. Low-protein diets or timing levodopa away from meals can reduce competition for transport across the gut/BBB, modestly ameliorating wearing-off.
3. Continuous subcutaneous apomorphine infusion or levodopa-carbidopa intestinal gel are palliative for refractory wearing-off by providing steady plasma levels.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Confusing “on-off” unpredictability (random motor fluctuations) with wearing-off (predictable end-dose failure).
2. Assuming all motor fluctuations stem from GI absorption issues rather than central storage failure.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. Movement Disorder Society (MDS) Evidence-Based Review (Espay et al, 2020)
– Recommendation: Treat wearing-off by optimizing levodopa delivery (Level A).
2. NICE Parkinson’s Disease Guideline CG35 (2017)
– Recommendation: Consider COMT inhibitors when end-of-dose deterioration occurs (Grade B).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Loss of SNpc dopaminergic neurons reduces innervation of the dorsal striatum (putamen), impairing modulation of the direct (facilitates movement) and indirect (inhibits movement) basal ganglia pathways. Depletion narrows the therapeutic window for exogenous levodopa.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Progressive α-synuclein aggregation and neuronal apoptosis in SNpc diminish vesicular dopamine storage. With fewer terminals, exogenous levodopa cannot be buffered, leading to pulsatile receptor activation and motor fluctuations.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Levodopa half-life: 1.5–2 h. COMT inhibitors extend half-life by blocking peripheral methylation. MAO-B inhibitors reduce central dopamine breakdown. Strategy: increase dosing frequency, add adjuncts, or use infusion pumps to approximate CDS.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2021 exam. Motor fluctuations in PD—wearing-off, peak-dose dyskinesia, on-off phenomenon—are high-yield topics tested frequently as single best-answer questions on pathophysiology and management.

question_text: A female patient has a tremor and her father has a tremor; the father reported that his tremor is improved with wine. What is the diagnosis?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2021] Tremors are rhythmic, involuntary oscillations classified by their relationship to voluntary movement.
• Essential tremor (ET): an action/postural tremor, often bilateral and symmetric, with autosomal dominant inheritance.
• Alcohol responsiveness is a hallmark: 50–70% of ET patients note transient improvement after ethanol ingestion.
• Differential includes Parkinson’s disease (resting tremor), cerebellar tremor (intention tremor with dysmetria), and dystonic tremor (irregular, posture-dependent).
Understanding these core distinctions—movement phase, distribution, family history, and modulating factors—is critical to accurate diagnosis.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Essential tremor is the correct diagnosis. The 2018 American Academy of Neurology (AAN) practice guideline (Chou et al., 2018, Level A evidence) identifies family history and alcohol responsiveness as key diagnostic clues. ET arises from cerebellothalamocortical circuit dysfunction, with Purkinje cell GABAergic abnormalities demonstrated in postmortem studies (Louis et al., 2013). Clinical evaluation revealing bilateral, high-frequency (4–12 Hz) postural tremor exacerbated by action, improvement with low-dose ethanol, and positive first-degree relative history aligns with consensus criteria (MDS Tremor Task Force, 2018). Pharmacotherapy (e.g., propranolol, primidone) targets the aberrant oscillatory network, whereas disease-modifying treatments remain investigational.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Parkinson’s disease
• Incorrect because PD tremor is predominantly a 4–6 Hz resting tremor, asymmetric, accompanied by bradykinesia and rigidity. Alcohol does not improve PD tremor.
C. Cerebellar tremor
• Intention tremor appears during terminal part of goal-directed movement, often with dysmetria and ataxia; not alcohol-responsive or familial in this pattern.
D. Dystonic tremor
• Tremor linked to sustained muscle contractions, irregular frequency, posture-specific “null points,” and geste antagoniste; no consistent alcohol benefit.

Comparison Table

FeatureEssential TremorParkinson’s Disease TremorCerebellar TremorDystonic Tremor
Tremor typePostural/actionRestingIntentionTask/posture-specific
Frequency4–12 Hz4–6 Hz<5 HzVariable, irregular
SymmetryBilateral, symmetricOften unilateral initiallyVariableAsymmetric, focal
Alcohol responsivenessImproves in 50–70%NoNoNo
Associated signsNoneBradykinesia, rigidityAtaxia, dysmetriaDystonic posturing, geste

Clinical Pearls

• A single sip of wine or beer improving tremor is nearly pathognomonic for essential tremor.
• First-line pharmacotherapy per AAN: propranolol (start 40 mg/day) or primidone (start 25 mg/day).
• Deep brain stimulation of the ventral intermediate nucleus of the thalamus offers sustained benefit in medication-refractory ET.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Mislabeling all postural tremors as cerebellar when ET is far more common.
2. Assuming alcohol ‘makes everyone’s tremor better’—only ET shows reproducible short-term improvement.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. American Academy of Neurology (2018): ET treatment guideline recommends propranolol or primidone as Level A therapies; topiramate as Level B.
2. Movement Disorder Society Consensus (2021): endorses MR-guided focused ultrasound thalamotomy in select ET patients refractory to medications (Level B evidence).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

ET involves abnormal oscillations within the cerebellothalamocortical loop. Purkinje cell loss and reduced GABAergic output in the cerebellar dentate nucleus lead to thalamic relay hyperactivity.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Genetic mutations (e.g., ETM1 locus on chromosome 3q13) predispose to Purkinje cell dysfunction. Reduced GABA receptor density and altered calcium channel function amplify tremorogenic oscillations.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Detailed history: tremor phase, family history, alcohol response.
2. Neurological exam: characterize frequency, distribution, rest vs. action.
3. Exclude red flags: ataxia, rigidity, bradykinesia, dystonic postures.
4. Consider DAT-SPECT if PD uncertain; normal imaging supports ET.

Neuroimaging Pearls

Structural MRI is typically unremarkable in ET; DAT-SPECT distinguishes ET (normal uptake) from PD (reduced striatal uptake).

Pharmacotherapy Focus

• Propranolol: nonselective β-blocker, 30–320 mg/day, titrate to tremor suppression.
• Primidone: barbiturate prodrug to phenobarbital, 50–250 mg/day; monitor for sedation.
• Second-line: topiramate, gabapentin; advanced: DBS, MRgFUS.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2021 exam. Essential tremor is frequently tested as an action tremor with characteristic alcohol responsiveness and autosomal dominant inheritance, often contrasted with Parkinsonian, cerebellar, and dystonic tremors.

question_text: In a case of multiple system atrophy (MSA), what radiological finding is commonly associated?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2022] Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic α-synucleinopathy characterized by neurodegeneration in striatonigral and olivopontocerebellar pathways, producing parkinsonian (MSA-P) and cerebellar (MSA-C) phenotypes. In MSA-C, selective loss of transverse pontine fibers and raphe nuclei produces a cruciform T2/FLAIR hyperintensity in the pons—the “hot cross bun” sign. Key structures: pontine basis, middle cerebellar peduncles, and putamen. Distinguishing MSA from mimics (e.g., multiple sclerosis, glioblastoma) relies on recognition of specific neuroimaging signatures.

Evidence-Based Analysis

The hot cross bun sign arises from degeneration of pontocerebellar fibers intersecting transverse pontine fibers, yielding a cruciate hyperintensity on axial T2/FLAIR MRI (Ozawa et al., Brain 2004). Paviour et al. (Mov Disord 2006) reported specificity >95% for MSA-C versus spinocerebellar ataxias. The 2022 Movement Disorder Society MSA diagnostic criteria include the hot cross bun sign as a supportive imaging marker (Level IV evidence). Additional MRI features—putaminal hypointensity with a hyperintense rim (“putaminal rim sign”) and middle cerebellar peduncle atrophy—reinforce the diagnosis. Other options reflect distinct pathologies: Dawson’s fingers in MS, butterfly glioma in glioblastoma multiforme, and ring-enhancing lesions in abscess or metastatic disease.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Dawson’s fingers
• Represent perivenular demyelinating lesions perpendicular to ventricles in MS (not MSA).
• Misconception: conflating demyelination patterns with neurodegenerative atrophy.

C. Butterfly glioma
• Describes glioblastoma crossing the corpus callosum, forming bifrontal masses.
• Misconception: assuming any cross-shaped lesion implies MSA.

D. Ring-enhancing lesion
• Seen in abscesses, metastases or high-grade tumors with blood–brain barrier breakdown.
• Differs from non-enhancing, degenerative changes in MSA.

Comparison Table

FeatureHot Cross Bun SignDawson’s FingersButterfly GliomaRing-Enhancing Lesion
Imaging modalityT2/FLAIR MRIT2/FLAIR MRIT1 + contrast MRIT1 + contrast MRI
AppearanceCruciform pontine hyperintensityOvoid periventricular lesionsBilateral frontal masses crossing corpus callosumPeripheral ring enhancement
Associated conditionMSA-CMultiple sclerosisGlioblastoma multiformeAbscess, metastasis
PathophysiologyDegeneration of pontocerebellar fibersPerivenular demyelinationInfiltrative neoplasmBlood–brain barrier disruption

Clinical Pearls

- MSA subtypes: parkinsonian (MSA-P) vs cerebellar (MSA-C); hot cross bun is most prominent in MSA-C.
• Specificity of the hot cross bun sign for MSA-C exceeds 90%; sensitivity varies by disease stage.
• Rarely, spinocerebellar ataxia type 2 may mimic the hot cross bun sign—correlate clinically.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Overcalling pontine T2 changes as demyelination (MS) rather than neurodegeneration (MSA).
• Assuming ring enhancement excludes neurodegenerative processes—contrast uptake patterns differ.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- Movement Disorder Society MSA diagnostic criteria (MDS, 2022): include hot cross bun sign as a supportive imaging feature (Level IV evidence).
• Consensus Statement on Neuroimaging in MSA (European Radiology, 2023): hot cross bun sign sensitivity ~65%, specificity ~95% for MSA-C vs SCA and PD.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Degeneration of transverse pontine fibers (originating in pontine nuclei) and raphe interconnections creates the cruciform signal; involvement of middle cerebellar peduncles explains concomitant ataxia.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Oligodendroglial cytoplasmic inclusions of α-synuclein trigger gliosis and axonal loss in pontocerebellar tracts, sparing blood–brain barrier integrity and thus lacking contrast enhancement.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion: autonomic failure + parkinsonism/ataxia.
2. Exclude mimics via laboratory and CSF studies (e.g., oligoclonal bands).
3. MRI T2/FLAIR: evaluate for hot cross bun, putaminal rim sign.
4. Support diagnosis with neurophysiological tests (e.g., autonomic reflex screening).

Neuroimaging Pearls

- Use high-resolution T2 and FLAIR sequences through pons.
• Assess putamen for hypointensity with lateral rim hyperintensity (“putaminal rim sign”).

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part II 2022 exam. MSA imaging features are high-yield for boards, frequently tested as single-best-answer questions on MRI signs.

question_text: A 62-year-old woman has experienced progressive unsteady gait and recurrent falls over the past 3 years, accompanied by urinary urgency progressing to incontinence. Brain MRI demonstrates prominent midbrain atrophy with a “hummingbird” appearance. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2022] Progressive supranuclear palsy (PSP) is an atypical parkinsonian tauopathy marked by early postural instability, vertical supranuclear gaze palsy, axial rigidity, and frontal cognitive changes. Key neuroanatomical sites include the midbrain tegmentum—atrophied in PSP (“hummingbird sign”)—and superior cerebellar peduncles. Pathophysiologically, 4-repeat tau aggregates accumulate in neurons and glia, causing neuronal loss in basal ganglia and brainstem. Clinically, falls within the first 1–2 years of onset distinguish PSP from Parkinson’s disease. Urinary dysfunction arises from brainstem autonomic involvement but is less prominent than in MSA. Recognizing imaging biomarkers alongside early clinical red flags is essential for diagnosis.

Evidence-Based Analysis

PSP meets the 2017 Movement Disorder Society (MDS) criteria: early falls (<3 years), vertical supranuclear gaze palsy, and supportive MRI showing midbrain atrophy (medial midbrain atrophy with preservation of pons). Whitwell et al. (Neurology, 2013) demonstrated that midbrain area < 70 mm² yields 90% specificity. MDS guidelines (Litvan et al., 2017) assign Level A diagnostic validity to these features. Unlike PD or MSA, PSP shows minimal levodopa responsiveness and absence of pontocerebellar “hot cross bun” sign. Diagnosis is clinched by correlating horizontal ocular pursuits, axial rigidity, early falls, and imaging.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Multiple System Atrophy (MSA)
– MRI in MSA-cerebellar type shows pontine hot cross bun sign and cerebellar atrophy, not isolated midbrain atrophy.
– Rapid autonomic failure (orthostasis, severe urinary retention) precedes gait issues; ocular motility preserved.
– Misconception: all atypical parkinsonisms have early urinary incontinence.

C. Normal Pressure Hydrocephalus (NPH)
– Presents with magnetic gait, cognitive decline, urinary incontinence, but MRI shows enlarged ventricles with tight sulci, not midbrain atrophy.
– Gait is “magnetic” and wide-based; ocular motility intact.
– Misconception: any gait + incontinence = NPH.

D. Corticobasal Degeneration (CBD)
– Asymmetric cortical signs (ideomotor apraxia, alien limb), cortical sensory loss, “claw hand,” not early falls or midbrain atrophy.
– MRI shows asymmetric frontoparietal atrophy.
– Misconception: CBD and PSP share midbrain atrophy (they do not).

Comparison Table

FeaturePSPMSANPHCBD
Early falls (<3 yrs)YesOccasionally lateNoRare
Vertical gaze palsySupranuclear palsy presentAbsentAbsentAbsent
MRI midbrain atrophyProminent (“hummingbird sign”)NoNo (ventricular enlargement)No (frontoparietal atrophy)
Autonomic failureMild urinary urgency/incontinenceSevere orthostasis, urinaryUrinary incontinence commonRare
Cortical signsFrontal cognitive deficitsMinimalVariableApraxia, cortical sensory deficits

Clinical Pearls

• Early postural instability with falls (<3 years) strongly suggests PSP over PD or MSA.
• The “hummingbird” or “penguin silhouette” sign on mid-sagittal MRI is highly specific for PSP.
• Vertical supranuclear gaze palsy may begin with slowed vertical saccades; test with downward gaze first.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Assuming urinary incontinence early in disease always indicates MSA or NPH.
2. Overlooking vertical gaze testing and attributing falls to peripheral neuropathy or cerebellar ataxia.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• Movement Disorder Society (MDS) PSP Criteria, Litvan et al., 2017: Defines Level A validity for early falls, vertical supranuclear gaze palsy, and midbrain atrophy on MRI.
• European Academy of Neurology (EAN) Guidelines on Atypical Parkinsonism, 2022: Recommends MRI measurement of midbrain tegmental area and superior cerebellar peduncle thickness for differential diagnosis (Level B evidence).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

PSP targets midbrain nuclei (oculomotor complex, vertical gaze centers) and superior cerebellar peduncles. Tau deposition in the subthalamic nucleus and globus pallidus disrupts basal ganglia circuits, leading to axial rigidity and postural instability.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

PSP is a 4R‐tauopathy with neuronal and glial tau aggregates. Tau hyperphosphorylation disrupts microtubule stability, leading to neuronal loss in brainstem and basal ganglia. Accumulation in the subthalamic nucleus impairs inhibitory outputs, causing rigidity and gait failure.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion: early falls, axial rigidity
2. Ocular exam: test vertical saccades/pursuits
3. MRI brain: measure midbrain area/SCP thickness
4. Apply MDS PSP diagnostic criteria
5. Exclude alternative causes (NPH, MSA, CBD)

Neuroimaging Pearls

• Mid-sagittal MRI: midbrain tegmentum atrophy (“hummingbird sign”).
• MR Parkinsonism Index > 13.5 (ratio pons/midbrain × MCP/SCP) differentiates PSP from MSA-P.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

• Levodopa trial: typically poor or transient response.
• Amantadine may modestly improve gait freezing.
• Physical and occupational therapy crucial for fall prevention.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part II 2022 exam. Atypical parkinsonian syndromes are frequently tested on boards, often emphasizing early falls, vertical gaze palsy, and characteristic MRI signs in PSP.

question_text: A young man who is a law student in the last year of college has a long-standing intentional tremor that has worsened over the past few months. He has bronchial asthma and is on inhalers. What is the most appropriate treatment?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2024] Essential Tremor (ET) is a common action tremor—postural and kinetic—that often worsens with goal-directed movements. It arises from abnormal oscillatory activity in the cerebello-thalamo-cortical circuit. First-line pharmacotherapy per American Academy of Neurology (AAN) guidelines includes nonselective β-blockers (propranolol) and the barbiturate analogue primidone. Comorbidities (e.g., asthma) dictate drug choice: nonselective β-blockade can precipitate bronchospasm. Secondary agents (topiramate, gabapentin) have lower-level evidence and more adverse effects.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Primidone is a first-line agent (Level A evidence, AAN 2018) that metabolizes to phenobarbital, enhancing GABA_A-mediated inhibition in cerebellar and thalamic circuits, reducing tremor amplitude by 50–70% in RCTs (Koller et al., 1994; Louis et al., 2001). Dosing begins at 12.5 mg nightly, titrating by 12.5 mg increments weekly up to 250–500 mg/day as tolerated. Propranolol shares similar efficacy but is contraindicated in asthma due to nonselective β_2 blockade causing bronchoconstriction. Topiramate (Level C) and gabapentin (Level U) show modest benefit in small trials but carry cognitive side effects or limited efficacy.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Propranolol
• Contraindicated in bronchial asthma—nonselective β_2 blockade precipitates bronchospasm.
• Misconception: All first-line tremor drugs are interchangeable without regard to comorbidities.

C. Topiramate
• Second-/third-line (Level C evidence); cognitive slowing, paresthesias, weight loss limit tolerability.
• Misconception: Antiepileptics are equally potent as primidone/propranolol for ET.

D. Gabapentin
• Off-label, limited RCT data (small open‐label studies); efficacy <30%.
• Misconception: All anticonvulsants have robust tremor‐suppressing effects.

Comparison Table

FeaturePrimidonePropranololTopiramateGabapentin
Drug classBarbiturate analogueNonselective β-blockerAntiepileptic (sulfamate)Antiepileptic (GABA analogue)
Mechanism↑ GABA_A inhibition↓ Peripheral β_1/β_2 activity↓ AMPA/kainate neurotransmission↑ GABA release
Evidence level (ET)A (AAN 2018)A (AAN 2018)C (AAN 2018)U (insufficient)
Typical dosing12.5 mg→250–500 mg/day40–320 mg/day50–300 mg/day900–3600 mg/day
Key side effectsSedation, ataxiaBradycardia, fatigue, bronchospasmCognitive impairment, paresthesiasSomnolence, dizziness
Asthma safetySafeContraindicatedSafeSafe

Clinical Pearls

• Always review comorbidities—nonselective β-blockers (propranolol, nadolol) can exacerbate asthma.
• Primidone requires slow titration to minimize sedation and ataxia; patient education on dose adjustments is vital.
• Consider referral for deep brain stimulation if pharmacotherapy fails or side effects are intolerable.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Interpreting “intentional tremor” as cerebellar disease only—ET is a kinetic tremor that may appear during target-directed movement.
2. Selecting propranolol without screening for respiratory disease, risking severe bronchospasm.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• AAN Practice Guideline on Essential Tremor (2018): Recommends primidone and propranolol as first-line (Level A), topiramate as second-line (Level C), gabapentin not recommended due to insufficient evidence.
• European Federation of Neurological Societies (EFNS) Guidelines (2011): Echo similar hierarchy; notes primidone’s superior tolerability in patients contraindicated for β-blockers.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

ET arises from dysrhythmia in the cerebello-thalamo-cortical loop. Abnormal pacemaker activity in the inferior olive and Purkinje cell loss in the cerebellar cortex contribute to overactive thalamic relay in the ventral intermediate nucleus, producing rhythmic tremor.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

ET involves GABAergic dysfunction and increased oscillatory synchrony between the deep cerebellar nuclei and thalamus. Primidone’s GABA_A potentiation restores inhibitory tone, dampening tremorogenic circuits.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Primidone: Start 12.5 mg at bedtime, increase by 12.5 mg weekly; monitor for sedation, adjust to symptom control. Educate on phenobarbital metabolite effects. Monitor liver function periodically.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2024 exam. Essential tremor pharmacotherapy is frequently tested—expect vignettes highlighting comorbidities (e.g., asthma) that contraindicate β-blockers and require selection of primidone.

question_text: What medication is commonly used to treat essential tremor in a patient with asthma?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2018] Essential tremor (ET) is a postural and kinetic tremor implicating the cerebellothalamocortical loop and likely reflecting GABAergic dysfunction in the dentate nucleus. First-line pharmacotherapy targets either β-adrenergic receptors (propranolol) or GABA modulation (primidone). In asthma, nonselective β-blockade precipitates bronchoconstriction; thus, primidone—a barbiturate analog metabolized to phenobarbital—becomes the agent of choice. Understanding drug metabolism, receptor selectivity, and contraindications is critical when tailoring ET treatment.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Primidone has Class I evidence (AAN 2018 Practice Guideline) demonstrating tremor amplitude reduction by ~50–60% in randomized, placebo-controlled trials. It enhances GABA_A receptor–mediated inhibition in cerebellar circuits. Propranolol also enjoys Level A support but is contraindicated in reactive airway disease due to β_2-receptor blockade. Gabapentin shows modest benefit (Level B) in small RCTs, while diazepam lacks robust evidence and carries risk of tolerance, sedation, and respiratory depression. Current consensus (Movement Disorders Society 2020) affirms primidone as first-line when β-blockers are contraindicated (Level II evidence).

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Propranolol
– Incorrect: Nonselective β_1/β_2-blocker; β_2 antagonism triggers bronchoconstriction in asthma.
– Misconception: All beta-blockers are interchangeable; in reality, β_1-selective agents (e.g., metoprolol) are safer in mild COPD but still avoided in asthma.

C. Diazepam
– Incorrect: Benzodiazepine with GABA_A potentiation lacks strong RCT support for ET; risk of tolerance, dependence, and sedation.
– Misconception: Any GABAergic agent is equally effective; primidone’s barbiturate metabolite has superior tremor suppression.

D. Gabapentin
– Incorrect: α2δ calcium-channel modulator with only Level B evidence and less efficacy than primidone or propranolol; side effects include dizziness and ataxia.
– Misconception: Newer antiepileptics outperform classic agents; in ET, they are generally second-line.

Comparison Table

FeaturePrimidonePropranololDiazepamGabapentin
MechanismBarbiturate→phenobarbital→GABA_A ↑Nonselective β_1/β_2-blockerGABA_A allosteric modulatorα2δ subunit calcium-channel modulator
Evidence LevelA (Class I RCTs)A (Class I RCTs)C (open-label, anecdotal)B (small RCTs)
EfficacyTremor ↓ 50–60%Tremor ↓ 50%Minimal, variableTremor ↓ ~30%
Key Side EffectsSedation, nausea, cytopeniasBronchoconstriction, bradycardiaSedation, tolerance, respiratory ↓Dizziness, somnolence
Asthma ConsiderationSafeContraindicatedCaution (respiratory depression)Safe but less effective

Clinical Pearls

- Titrate primidone slowly (e.g., start 12.5 mg nightly, increase by 12.5–25 mg weekly) to minimize sedation and dizziness.
• Monitor blood counts and liver function after chronic primidone use for cytopenias/hepatic toxicity.
• In refractory ET, consider deep brain stimulation targeting the ventral intermediate nucleus of the thalamus.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Prescribing propranolol universally for ET without assessing pulmonary comorbidities.
2. Overestimating the role of benzodiazepines, leading to sedative dependence rather than tremor control.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- American Academy of Neurology (2018): Recommends primidone or propranolol as first-line agents for ET (Level A evidence).
• Movement Disorders Society Consensus (2020): Affirms primidone in patients with contraindications to β-blockers (Level II evidence); supports DBS for medication-refractory cases.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part II 2018 exam. On board examinations, ET pharmacotherapy is frequently tested via clinical vignettes emphasizing comorbidities (e.g., asthma) that contraindicate beta-blockers. Select primidone when nonselective β-blockade poses risk.

question_text: If a patient with orthostatic tremor does not respond to clonazepam, what is the next step in management?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2022] Orthostatic tremor is a rare high-frequency (13–18 Hz) tremor of the leg muscles on standing, leading to a sense of unsteadiness that rapidly abates with walking or sitting. Pathophysiology likely involves abnormal oscillatory activity in cerebello-thalamo-cortical circuits and segmental spinal pathways. Clonazepam, a benzodiazepine that potentiates GABA_A-mediated inhibition, is first-line therapy. In patients who remain symptomatic despite adequate clonazepam dosing, second-line agents targeting alternative neurotransmitter systems—particularly calcium channel modulation—are indicated.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Gabapentin binds the α2δ subunit of voltage-gated calcium channels, reducing excitatory neurotransmission in both spinal and supraspinal circuits implicated in orthostatic tremor. In multiple small case series (e.g., Singer et al., 2003; Gerschlager et al., 2004), gabapentin produced ≥50 % symptomatic improvement in 60–70 % of clonazepam-refractory patients. The Movement Disorder Society Evidence-Based Review of Treatment of Tremor (2018) classifies gabapentin as “possibly effective” (Level C) for orthostatic tremor, making it the preferred second-line agent. Neither levodopa (which targets dopaminergic deficiency) nor levetiracetam (SV2A modulation with only anecdotal reports) address the core pathophysiology, and primidone yields lower response rates with higher sedation risk.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. L-Dopa
• Incorrect because orthostatic tremor is not a dopaminergic deficit and does not respond to levodopa therapy.
• Misconception: equating all tremors with Parkinsonian tremor.
• Lacks both pathophysiologic rationale and clinical trial support.

C. Primidone
• Primidone metabolizes to phenobarbital, enhancing GABA_A activity, but shows only ~30 % efficacy in small series.
• Misconception: treating orthostatic tremor like essential tremor.
• Compared to gabapentin, it has a less favorable efficacy-to-sedation ratio.

D. Levetiracetam
• Modulates synaptic vesicle protein 2A (SV2A) but has only isolated case reports of benefit.
• Misconception: assuming broad-spectrum anticonvulsants are interchangeable.
• Lacks controlled studies and consistent clinical improvement.

Comparison Table

FeatureGabapentinL-DopaPrimidoneLevetiracetam
Mechanismα2δ subunit of VGCC blockerDopamine precursorBarbiturate metabolite (GABA_A)SV2A protein modulation
Evidence levelPossibly effective (C)Not recommendedPossibly effective (C, low)Anecdotal only
Reported response rate~60–70 %0 %~30 %<20 % (case reports)
Common side effectsSomnolence, dizzinessDyskinesia, nauseaSedation, ataxiaFatigue, irritability
Typical dosing range900–3600 mg/day300–1200 mg/day125–1000 mg/day1000–3000 mg/day

Clinical Pearls

1. Confirm orthostatic tremor by surface EMG demonstrating 13–18 Hz bursts in leg muscles on standing.
2. Titrate clonazepam slowly up to 4 mg/day to balance efficacy and sedation before declaring treatment failure.
3. Gabapentin is the most evidence-backed second-line agent; monitor for dizziness and dose-related somnolence.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Equating orthostatic tremor with essential tremor and initiating propranolol or primidone as first-line therapy.
2. Presuming any high-frequency tremor responds to dopaminergic therapy and prescribing levodopa.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. Movement Disorder Society Evidence-Based Review of Treatment of Tremor (MDS, 2018): Clonazepam is “probably effective” (Level B); gabapentin is “possibly effective” (Level C) for orthostatic tremor.
2. EFNS/EAN Guideline on Diagnosis and Management of Tremor (European Journal of Neurology, 2018): Recommends clonazepam (Level B) and gabapentin (Level C) as first- and second-line pharmacotherapies in orthostatic tremor.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part II 2022 exam. Orthostatic tremor management is often tested in single-best-answer format, emphasizing the pharmacologic sequence after benzodiazepine therapy.

question_text: In a patient on risperidone, how can you differentiate tardive dyskinesia from Huntington’s disease?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2023] Tardive dyskinesia (TD) and Huntington’s disease (HD) both manifest with choreiform movements but arise from distinct pathophysiologies.
• Basal ganglia circuits: HD involves CAG-repeat–mediated neurodegeneration of striatal medium spiny neurons (caudate/putamen), disrupting the indirect pathway and causing chorea. TD reflects dopamine D2-receptor supersensitivity in nigrostriatal pathways after chronic antipsychotic blockade.
• Genetics vs. drug exposure: HD is autosomal dominant (HTT gene CAG expansion, near 100% penetrance), whereas TD is a late-onset extrapyramidal side effect of dopamine-blocking agents like risperidone.
• Clinical exam: HD shows impaired voluntary saccades and cognitive decline; TD has predominantly orolingual and limb chorea without cognitive impairment or saccadic slowing.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Family history is the most reliable discriminator: HD patients have a positive autosomal dominant pedigree in >90% of cases (Walker FO. Lancet Neurol. 2007). In contrast, TD arises de novo after ≥3 months of neuroleptic exposure (DSM-5 criteria), with no hereditary pattern. Current AAN practice guidelines (2018) emphasize thorough medication and family histories when evaluating new hyperkinetic movements. Genetic testing for HTT CAG repeats confirms HD; VMAT2 inhibitor trials (e.g., valbenazine, deutetrabenazine) support alleviation of TD but have no role in HD prevention or modification.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Lack of eye movement
• Why incorrect: HD is characterized by slowed voluntary saccades and impaired initiation of gaze shifts, not an absolute “lack.” TD spares oculomotor function.
• Misconception: Equating chorea severity with ocular motor arrest.
• Differentiator: Qualitative saccadic testing (velocity, latency) distinguishes HD from TD.

C. Presence of chorea
• Why incorrect: Both TD and HD present with choreiform movements; this feature does not differentiate.
• Misconception: Believing chorea is unique to one condition.
• Differentiator: Distribution and accompanying features (e.g., orofacial in TD vs. generalized in HD) are more subtle.

D. Age of onset
• Why incorrect: HD typically onsets at 30–50 years, but TD can also emerge in middle age after antipsychotic use. There is significant overlap.
• Misconception: Relying on arbitrary age cutoffs.
• Differentiator: Temporal relationship to drug initiation is more informative than patient age.

Comparison Table

FeatureTardive DyskinesiaHuntington’s Disease
Family historyNegative (sporadic)Positive, autosomal dominant
Medication associationChronic dopamine-blocker useNone
Voluntary saccadesNormalSlow, increased latency
Cognitive impairmentAbsentProgressive dementia
NeuroimagingTypically normalCaudate atrophy, increased bicaudate ratio

Clinical Pearls

- Always obtain a three-generation pedigree when chorea is unexplained or refractory to VMAT2 inhibitors.
• Oculomotor examination (saccades, pursuit) is a rapid bedside tool: slowed horizontal saccades point to HD.
• In TD, VMAT2 inhibitors (valbenazine, deutetrabenazine) are FDA-approved; they do not alter underlying receptor supersensitivity.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Mislabeling acute orofacial dyskinesias as TD without verifying duration (>1 month) and chronicity.
2. Assuming chorea in any psychotropic-treated patient is drug-induced without a family history or genetic test.
3. Overemphasizing age at presentation rather than temporal relation to neuroleptic use.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- American Academy of Neurology 2018 Practice Guideline: Recommends VMAT2 inhibitors (Level B evidence) as first-line for TD and stresses detailed medication/family history.
• European Huntington’s Disease Network 2021 Consensus: Advises genetic testing for HTT CAG repeats in all suspected HD cases and multidisciplinary care (Level A evidence).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

- TD: Functional upregulation of D2 receptors in the striatum (nigrostriatal pathway) leads to involuntary movements.
• HD: Degeneration of GABAergic medium spiny neurons in the caudate/putamen disrupts indirect pathway inhibition, causing chorea.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

- Tardive dyskinesia: Chronic D2 blockade → receptor supersensitivity → dysregulated motor output.
• Huntington’s disease: CAG expansion → mutant huntingtin protein → neuronal apoptosis via mitochondrial dysfunction and excitotoxicity.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Confirm chorea phenomenology on exam.
2. Review medication history (antipsychotic duration).
3. Elicit family history of movement disorders or dementia.
4. Perform oculomotor testing.
5. If HD suspected, order HTT CAG repeat analysis and brain MRI.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- HD: MRI shows caudate head atrophy, enlargement of frontal horns; bicaudate ratio >0.16 is highly sensitive.
• TD: Structural imaging is typically unremarkable.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- TD: Valbenazine 40 mg daily (titrate to 80 mg) or deutetrabenazine starting 12 mg twice daily, adjust for efficacy and side effects.
• HD: Tetrabenazine (start 12.5 mg/day) for chorea; monitor for depression.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2023 exam.
Choreiform movement differentiation between drug-induced and genetic etiologies is frequently tested on neurology board examinations, often requiring integration of family history, medication side effects, oculomotor findings, and genetic testing strategies.

question_text: In the same scenario, what is the next step in management?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2021] Idiopathic Parkinson’s disease (PD) is characterized by degeneration of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra pars compacta, leading to striatal dopamine deficiency. Key motor features include bradykinesia, resting tremor, rigidity, and postural instability. Symptomatic management aims to restore dopamine levels to improve activities of daily living. Levodopa, the metabolic precursor to dopamine, remains the most potent agent for moderate-to-severe symptoms. Adjunctive strategies (physiotherapy) and imaging (MRI) have supporting but not primary roles in initial management.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Levodopa is the gold-standard symptomatic therapy for PD when motor symptoms impair function. The PD MED trial (Lancet Neurol 2014) demonstrated superior quality-of-life improvement and motor control with levodopa versus initial dopamine agonist therapy (HR for treatment success 1.12; 95% CI 1.02–1.23). The 2018 Movement Disorder Society Evidence-Based Guidelines (Level A recommendation) endorse levodopa as first-line in patients >60 years or with significant disability. Early levodopa (ELLDOPA trial, Neurology 2004) also showed sustained benefit without accelerating progression. Its rapid onset and robust efficacy in improving bradykinesia and rigidity make it the appropriate next step.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Initiate dopamine agonist therapy
• Less efficacious in symptom control compared to levodopa.
• Reserved for younger patients (<60 years) to delay motor complications.
• Common misconception: agonists are equally potent; in reality they yield slower and less robust motor improvement.

C. Begin physical therapy and exercise
• Important adjunct to improve gait and balance, but insufficient as monotherapy when motor features significantly impair daily living.
• Misconception: that non-pharmacologic measures alone can replace dopamine replacement in moderate disease.

D. Order brain MRI to rule out other causes
• Routine neuroimaging not indicated in classic clinical PD without red flags (rapid progression, early falls, atypical signs).
• MRI is used to exclude secondary or atypical parkinsonism, not to guide initial pharmacotherapy.

Comparison Table

FeatureLevodopaDopamine AgonistPhysical TherapyBrain MRI
Primary RoleSymptomatic motor controlAdjunct/delay dyskinesiasGait, balance adjunctExclude secondary causes
Onset of ActionRapid (hours)Moderate (days–weeks)Gradual (weeks–months)Immediate imaging result
EfficacyHighestModerateSupportiveNone for symptom relief
Indicated WhenSignificant motor impairmentYounger patients, mild symptomsAt any stage as adjunctAtypical or red flag presentations
Long-term ComplicationsDyskinesias, motor fluctuationsImpulse control disordersMinimalIncidental findings

Clinical Pearls

• Levodopa/carbidopa remains the most potent treatment for symptomatic PD and should be started when motor signs impede daily function.
• Initiate levodopa at low dose (e.g., 100/25 mg TID) and titrate to balance efficacy and minimize dyskinesias.
• Encourage concurrent physical therapy early to maintain mobility, but do not delay dopamine replacement when indicated.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Delaying levodopa due to fear of dyskinesias: motor complications can be managed, while untreated bradykinesia impairs quality of life.
2. Over-reliance on imaging: normal MRI does not confirm PD, and structural scans rarely alter management in classic presentations.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• Movement Disorder Society (2018) Evidence-Based Medicine Review: Levodopa is Level A recommended first-line therapy for patients >60 years or with functional impairment.
• PD MED Trial (Lancet Neurol 2014): Demonstrated superior long-term quality-of-life and motor outcomes with initial levodopa versus dopamine agonists (n = 1,626; median follow-up 2 years).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Degeneration of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra pars compacta reduces nigrostriatal dopamine input to the dorsal striatum, disrupting the direct and indirect basal ganglia pathways and leading to bradykinesia and rigidity.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Alpha-synuclein aggregation forms Lewy bodies within dopaminergic neurons, triggering mitochondrial dysfunction, oxidative stress, and eventual neuronal death in the substantia nigra.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Levodopa crosses the blood–brain barrier and is decarboxylated to dopamine in the CNS. Co-administration with carbidopa inhibits peripheral decarboxylation, enhancing central availability and reducing peripheral side effects.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2021 exam. Parkinson’s disease management—particularly the choice and timing of levodopa initiation—is a high-yield topic frequently tested in vignette format, assessing knowledge of guidelines, trial data, and therapeutic hierarchy.

question_text: Q222. In a scenario of progressive supranuclear palsy (PSP), what is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2018] Progressive supranuclear palsy (PSP) is a primary tauopathy characterized by 4-repeat tau aggregation in basal ganglia, brainstem and cerebellar nuclei. Key neuroanatomical structures include the midbrain—particularly the rostral interstitial nucleus of the medial longitudinal fasciculus (riMLF) mediating vertical gaze—and the globus pallidus. Clinically, PSP presents with early postural instability leading to falls, vertical supranuclear gaze palsy (especially downgaze), axial rigidity, and poor levodopa responsiveness. Distinction from Parkinson’s disease rests on symmetry of symptoms, early fall risk, gaze abnormalities, and specific neuroimaging signs (hummingbird sign). Understanding these pathophysiological and anatomical hallmarks is critical to differentiate PSP from other movement disorders with overlapping features.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Progressive supranuclear palsy is defined by the Movement Disorder Society (MDS) 2017 criteria as a neurodegenerative tauopathy presenting with vertical gaze palsy, postural instability, and cognitive dysfunction in mid‐late life. Neuropathologically, widespread neuronal loss and gliosis with 4-repeat tau inclusions in tufted astrocytes are diagnostic (Dickson et al., 2010). MRI typically shows midbrain atrophy with preserved pons (“hummingbird” or “penguin” sign) and superior cerebellar peduncle thinning. Levodopa trials yield minimal benefit (<30% responders), unlike in Parkinson’s disease. Current guidelines (MDS PSP diagnostic criteria, 2017; Level A evidence) emphasize early falls and supranuclear gaze palsy as core features. No disease‐modifying therapy exists; management is supportive, targeting postural stability, speech, and swallowing.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Parkinson’s disease
• Incorrect: Asymmetric onset, resting tremor, marked levodopa responsiveness (>60%), and absence of early falls or vertical supranuclear gaze palsy.
• Misconception: All parkinsonian syndromes are PD. PSP is an atypical parkinsonism with distinct tau pathology.

B. Multiple sclerosis
• Incorrect: Demyelinating plaques on MRI, relapsing‐remitting course, optic neuritis, internuclear ophthalmoplegia rather than vertical gaze palsy, and younger onset (20–40 years).
• Misconception: Any ocular motor abnormality suggests MS; PSP gaze palsy is supranuclear and progressive.

D. Essential tremor
• Incorrect: Action/postural tremor of hands/head, improves with alcohol, no rigidity or bradykinesia, no gaze palsy, normal MRI.
• Misconception: Tremor in PSP might be confused with ET, but ET lacks axial rigidity and gaze dysfunction.

Comparison Table

FeaturePSP (Correct)Parkinson’s DiseaseMultiple SclerosisEssential Tremor
Onset age60–70 years55–65 years20–40 yearsAny, often >40 years
Initial symptomEarly falls, axial rigidityResting tremor, bradykinesiaSensory deficits, optic neuritisPostural/action tremor
Gaze abnormalityVertical supranuclear palsyRare; ocular dyskinesiasInternuclear ophthalmoplegiaNone
Levodopa responsivenessPoor (<30% benefit)Good (>60% benefit)Not indicatedNone
MRI findingsMidbrain atrophy (“hummingbird sign”)Substantia nigra signal lossPeriventricular/juxtacortical plaquesNormal

Clinical Pearls

- Early backward falls and vertical downgaze palsy are hallmark red flags for PSP.
• “Hummingbird sign” on sagittal MRI and superior cerebellar peduncle atrophy support PSP diagnosis.
• Poor levodopa response differentiates PSP from idiopathic Parkinson’s disease.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Misattributing early falls in PSP to peripheral neuropathy or lumbar stenosis rather than brainstem dysfunction.
2. Over-relying on rigidity and bradykinesia without testing supranuclear gaze, leading to misdiagnosis as PD.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- Movement Disorder Society PSP Diagnostic Criteria (2017): Defines probable PSP with postural instability and vertical gaze palsy; Level A evidence.
• Bero et al., JAMA Neurology (2020): Phase II trial of tau vaccine AADvac1 showed safety and target engagement, but no clinical efficacy demonstrated yet (Level B).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

PSP targets the midbrain (riMLF) causing vertical supranuclear gaze palsy, globus pallidus and subthalamic nucleus producing axial rigidity, and dentatorubrothalamic pathway leading to ataxia.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

4-repeat tau accumulates in neurons and glia (tufted astrocytes), leading to neurodegeneration in subcortical nuclei, midbrain tegmentum, and superior cerebellar peduncles.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion: age >60, early falls, axial rigidity.
2. Ocular exam: assess voluntary vertical gaze.
3. MRI brain: evaluate midbrain atrophy (“hummingbird sign”) and SCP thinning.
4. Levodopa trial: assess response.
5. Apply MDS 2017 criteria for probable/possible PSP.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- Sagittal mid-brain to pons ratio <0.52 suggests PSP.
• Superior cerebellar peduncle atrophy on axial imaging is supportive.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Levodopa trial (up to 1,500 mg/day) yields limited benefit; consider amantadine for gait freezing and botulinum toxin for eyelid apraxia.
• No disease-modifying agents approved; symptomatic management predominates.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part II 2018 exam.
PSP testing on boards often involves recognition of early falls, vertical gaze palsy, midbrain atrophy on MRI, and poor levodopa response to distinguish from PD.

question_text: Q203. What is the first-line treatment for Sydenham chorea?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2021] Sydenham chorea is a major manifestation of acute rheumatic fever, resulting from autoimmune cross-reactivity between group A streptococcal antigens and basal ganglia neurons. Key concepts:
• Pathophysiology: Molecular mimicry leads to antibody-mediated dysfunction in the striatum (caudate and putamen), causing irregular, involuntary movements.
• Neurophysiology: Dopaminergic overactivity in the basal ganglia–thalamocortical circuit underlies choreic movements; GABAergic and cholinergic systems are also involved.
• Therapeutic rationale: Dopamine D₂ receptor antagonists (e.g., haloperidol) reduce hyperkinetic movements by restoring inhibitory balance.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Haloperidol, a typical antipsychotic with high D₂ receptor affinity, remains first-line for Sydenham chorea (AHA 2015 guidelines, Class I, LOE B). Studies (e.g., Singer et al., 2018 cohort) report remission in >90% of patients within 2–4 weeks at low doses (0.1–0.5 mg/kg/day). Compared with valproic acid, haloperidol has more extensive historical data and guideline endorsement. The 2017 Cochrane review concluded both agents reduce chorea severity, but haloperidol’s rapid onset and well-characterized pharmacokinetics justify its primacy. Adjunctive corticosteroids are reserved for refractory or severe presentations.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Valproic acid
• Why incorrect: Although effective in moderate cases, valproate is second-line per AHA guidelines (Class IIa).
• Misconception: Assuming broad-spectrum anticonvulsants are always preferred; lacks the dopaminergic specificity of haloperidol.

C. Carbamazepine
• Why incorrect: Limited evidence in Sydenham chorea; primarily used in paroxysmal movement disorders (e.g., paroxysmal kinesigenic dyskinesia).
• Misconception: Equating all anticonvulsants as equally efficacious in chorea.

D. Prednisone
• Why incorrect: Corticosteroids modulate underlying inflammation but are reserved for severe, refractory chorea or concurrent carditis (Class IIb).
• Misconception: Overestimating the role of immunosuppression in initial symptomatic control.

Comparison Table

FeatureHaloperidol (Correct)Valproic AcidCarbamazepinePrednisone
MechanismD₂ receptor antagonism↑ GABAergic toneNa⁺ channel blockadeBroad immunosuppression
Onset of action24–72 hours3–7 daysVariable; slower in chorea1–2 weeks
Guideline statusFirst-line (AHA Class I, LOE B)Second-line (Class IIa)Not recommendedAdjunctive (Class IIb)
Common adverse effectsExtrapyramidal symptoms, tardive dyskinesiaHepatotoxicity, thrombocytopeniaHyponatremia, sedationWeight gain, mood changes
Evidence baseMultiple cohorts, expert consensusSeveral case seriesAnecdotal reportsSmall trials for refractory

Clinical Pearls

- Sydenham chorea may present months after pharyngitis; always ask about remote strep infections.
• Low-dose haloperidol (0.1 mg/kg/day) often suffices; titrate slowly to minimize EPS.
• Ensure long-term penicillin prophylaxis to prevent recurrence and mitigate rheumatic heart disease.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Prescribing corticosteroids as monotherapy for chorea—delays symptomatic relief and exposes to steroid risks.
• Misdiagnosing Sydenham chorea as tic disorders or Huntington’s—fails to address underlying rheumatic process.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- American Heart Association (AHA) 2015 Rheumatic Fever Guideline: Recommends haloperidol as first-line for chorea (Class I, LOE B).
• Cochrane Review (2017): Both haloperidol and valproate reduce chorea severity; haloperidol has faster onset.
• UpToDate (2024): Supports haloperidol initiation, with valproate reserved for haloperidol-intolerant cases.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Chorea originates from dysfunction in the striatum (caudate and putamen), leading to reduced inhibitory GABAergic output to the globus pallidus interna and excessive thalamocortical excitation.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Antistreptococcal antibodies cross-react with neuronal surface antigens (e.g., lysoganglioside GM1) in the basal ganglia, triggering inflammatory cascades and altered neurotransmitter balance.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical recognition of choreiform movements in a child/adolescent.
2. Evaluate for preceding streptococcal infection (ASO titers, anti-DNase B).
3. Assess for other rheumatic fever criteria (migratory arthritis, carditis).
4. Initiate symptomatic therapy (haloperidol) and antibiotic prophylaxis.

Neuroimaging Pearls

Brain MRI is typically normal; functional imaging (SPECT) may show basal ganglia hyperperfusion but is not routine.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Haloperidol dosing: start 0.1–0.2 mg/kg/day in divided doses; monitor for EPS and QT prolongation.
• Valproic acid alternative: 20–30 mg/kg/day; monitor liver enzymes and platelets.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2021 exam. Sydenham chorea management is frequently tested as a vignette requiring identification of first-line pharmacotherapy, emphasizing antipsychotic over immunosuppressive agents.

question_text: A patient with Parkinson’s disease has developed dystonia that is not improving with treatment. What is the next step?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2021] Parkinson’s disease (PD) involves degeneration of nigrostriatal dopaminergic neurons, disrupting the balance between the direct (facilitatory) and indirect (inhibitory) basal ganglia pathways.
• Dystonia in PD often arises from dopaminergic fluctuations (“off” dystonia) or peak-dose dyskinesia.
• Anticholinergic agents like trihexyphenidyl restore cholinergic–dopaminergic balance in the striatum, reducing dystonic muscle contractions.
• Recognizing dystonia subtypes (morning “off” dystonia, diphasic dystonia) guides therapy: adjust dopaminergic regimen or add adjuvant drugs.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Trihexyphenidyl is an anticholinergic that improves dystonic posturing by antagonizing muscarinic receptors in the striatum, thereby rebalancing excess cholinergic activity when dopaminergic tone is low. The 2018 MDS evidence-based review on dystonia management cites trihexyphenidyl (Class I/Level A evidence) as first-line oral therapy for generalized and segmental dystonia in younger PD patients. A randomized trial (Jankovic et al., 2019) demonstrated a 40% reduction in dystonic severity scores at 6 weeks versus placebo. In contrast, increasing levodopa or dopamine agonists may exacerbate peak-dose dystonia or cause dyskinesias. Propranolol has no efficacy in dystonia, and pramipexole lacks anticholinergic action.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Propranolol
• Incorrect: Beta-blockers treat action tremor (e.g., essential tremor) by reducing peripheral β-adrenergic activity, not dystonia.
• Misconception: All movement disorders respond to propranolol.
• Differentiator: No central anticholinergic or GABAergic action.

B. Levodopa
• Incorrect: Further increasing levodopa can worsen peak-dose dystonia and dyskinesias once optimal dosing is reached.
• Misconception: More dopamine uniformly improves all PD motor complications.
• Differentiator: Off-period dystonia may respond to timing adjustments rather than dose escalation.

C. Pramipexol
• Incorrect: Dopamine agonists can precipitate or worsen dyskinesias/dystonia and lack anticholinergic properties.
• Misconception: Any augmentation of dopaminergic therapy alleviates dystonia.
• Differentiator: No proven anti-dystonic effect.

Comparison Table

FeatureTrihexyphenidylPropranololLevodopaPramipexol
MechanismMuscarinic antagonistβ-adrenergic blockerDopamine precursorD2/D3 receptor agonist
Target symptomDystonia, tremorAction tremorBradykinesia, rigidityBradykinesia, rigidity
Dystonia efficacyProven (Level A)NoneMay worsen at high dosesNo evidence
Main side effectsCognitive decline, dry mouthBradycardia, hypotensionDyskinesias, nauseaImpulse control, edema

Clinical Pearls

• Early-morning “off” dystonia can also respond to a bedtime dose of long-acting levodopa or long-acting dopamine agonists, but trihexyphenidyl remains first-line for persistent dystonia in younger patients.
• Use the lowest effective trihexyphenidyl dose (1–2 mg TID) to minimize cognitive side effects in PD.
