Cognitive DeclineYes (subcortical dementia)Yes (mild dementia)Yes (adult form)Rare
Key Diagnostic CluesCAG repeat PCR; caudate atrophyAcanthocytes; chorea+neuropathyGenetic test ATN1; rare outside JapanKF rings; ceruloplasmin ↓

Clinical Pearls

- Anticipation: CAG repeats often expand during paternal transmission, leading to earlier onset in offspring.
• “Box‐car” ventricles on MRI reflect caudate atrophy; useful early imaging sign.
• First‐line chorea therapy is tetrabenazine (VMAT2 inhibitor); monitor for depression.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Attributing late‐onset chorea and dementia solely to Alzheimer’s or vascular dementia.
• Overlooking ataxia in HD as a nonspecific comorbidity rather than disease progression.
• Assuming lack of children or clear pedigree excludes autosomal dominant inheritance.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- European Huntington’s Disease Network (EHDN) Consensus (2023): Annual motor and cognitive assessments; predictive genetic testing only after structured counseling (Level B evidence).
• AAN Practice Parameter (2018) for Chorea: Recommends tetrabenazine or deutetrabenazine as Level A treatments for HD chorea.
• PREDICT‐HD (Paulsen JS et al. JNNP. 2014): Identified caudate atrophy on MRI up to 15 years before clinical onset.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Degeneration of GABAergic medium spiny neurons in the striatum disrupts the indirect pathway, causing disinhibition of the thalamus and chorea. Progressive cortical and cerebellar involvement accounts for cognitive decline and ataxia.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Mutant huntingtin with expanded polyglutamine tracts aggregates intracellularly, impairs proteasomal and mitochondrial function, and triggers excitotoxic neuronal death via NMDA receptor overactivation.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical assessment: chorea, cognitive/psychiatric changes.
2. MRI: evaluate caudate and putamen atrophy.
3. Genetic testing: PCR/Southern blot for CAG repeats in HTT.
4. Genetic counseling: discuss familial implications and predictive testing.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- Early MRI: caudate head atrophy → enlarged frontal horns (“box‐car” ventricles).
• FDG-PET: reduced glucose metabolism in caudate and putamen before symptom onset.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Tetrabenazine: start 12.5 mg daily, titrate to 50 mg/day; watch for depression.
• Deutetrabenazine: similar efficacy, improved tolerability; dose adjust in hepatic impairment.
• Atypical antipsychotics (e.g., olanzapine) for chorea with psychosis.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Promotion 2019 exam. HD vignettes frequently test the triad of chorea, cognitive decline, and autosomal dominant inheritance, as well as MRI findings (caudate atrophy) and genetic confirmation.

question_text: What is the most common familial gene associated with Parkinson's disease?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2018] Familial Parkinson’s disease (PD) arises from single‐gene mutations leading to early or adult‐onset parkinsonism.
1. LRRK2 encodes a kinase involved in vesicular trafficking and autophagy; G2019S is the most prevalent mutation.
2. PINK1 and parkin (PARK2) maintain mitochondrial quality via mitophagy; their mutations cause autosomal recessive, early‐onset PD.
3. SNCA encodes α‐synuclein, whose aggregation forms Lewy bodies; SNCA multiplications are rare familial PD causes.

Evidence-Based Analysis

LRRK2 mutations account for ~4–13% of familial and ~1–3% of sporadic PD worldwide. Healy et al. (Lancet Neurol 2008) screened 5,394 PD cases, finding LRRK2 G2019S in 13% of familial versus <1% with SNCA or PINK1. The 2018 MDS genetic testing guidelines recommend LRRK2 first in autosomal dominant PD (Level A evidence). LRRK2’s kinase domain hyperactivity promotes α-synuclein pathology; targeted inhibitors (e.g., DNL151) are in Phase 2 trials. Thus, LRRK2 is firmly established as the most common monogenic familial PD gene.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. PARK
– “PARK” is a locus designation, not a single gene; PARK2 (parkin) is an autosomal recessive gene with lower prevalence (~1–3% familial cases).
C. PINK1
– Causes early‐onset, autosomal recessive PD (<1% of familial cases). It affects mitochondrial serine/threonine kinase activity but is far less frequent than LRRK2.
D. SNCA
– First PD gene identified; multiplications cause dominantly inherited PD but represent <1% of familial cases. SNCA point mutations/multiplications are rare compared with LRRK2.

Comparison Table

GeneInheritanceApprox. Familial PrevalenceTypical Onset
LRRK2Autosomal Dominant4–13%Adult (50–70 yrs)
PARK2Autosomal Recessive1–3%Early (<40 yrs)
PINK1Autosomal Recessive<1%Early (<50 yrs)
SNCAAutosomal Dominant<1%Adult (40–60 yrs)

Clinical Pearls

• Founder mutations: LRRK2 G2019S is frequent in Ashkenazi Jews and North African Arabs.
• Penetrance: LRRK2 G2019S shows age‐dependent penetrance (~30% by age 60, ~70% by age 80).
• Therapeutic trials: LRRK2 kinase inhibitors (DNL151, BIIB122) target hyperactive LRRK2 and may modify disease.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Confusing risk genes with monogenic causes (e.g., GBA increases PD risk but is not a primary familial gene).
2. Assuming “PARK” denotes a single locus; students may overlook PARK2/PRKN versus generic PARK labeling.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• MDS Genetic Testing Recommendations (MDS, 2018): First‐line testing for LRRK2 in autosomal dominant PD (Level A).
• Denali Therapeutics Phase 2 Trial of DNL151 (2021): Demonstrated target engagement of LRRK2 kinase in cerebrospinal fluid (Proof of Principle, Level B).

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Promotion 2018 exam. Parkinson’s genetics are frequently tested as single best‐answer items, often focusing on LRRK2’s role and founder mutations.

question_text: An 11-year-old boy comes to the office with his parents because of a 14-month history of motor and vocal tics… Which of the following is the most appropriate description of this patient’s symptoms?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2018] Tic disorders arise from dysfunction in cortico-striato-thalamo-cortical circuits involving the basal ganglia and prefrontal cortex, leading to sudden, stereotyped motor or vocal movements.
DSM-5 classifies tics by duration and type:
• Transient (provisional) tic disorder: single/multiple motor or vocal tics, <12 months.
• Chronic motor or vocal tic disorder: single type only, >12 months.
• Tourette syndrome: ≥2 motor tics + ≥1 vocal tic, present >12 months, onset <18 years.
Stereotypies are rhythmic, prolonged, often seen in younger children or autism, and lack the suppressibility and variability of tics.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Tourette syndrome (TS) is defined by the DSM-5 (2013) as multiple motor tics plus at least one vocal tic, with symptom duration exceeding one year and onset before age 18. This patient has both motor (e.g., eye blinking, shoulder shrugging) and vocal (throat clearing, sniffing) tics for 14 months, fitting TS criteria exactly. The American Academy of Neurology’s 2019 practice guideline (Pringsheim et al.) confirms that diagnosis hinges on tic type and duration, not severity. Neurophysiologically, TS is linked to disinhibition within the indirect pathway of the basal ganglia, leading to overflow movements. Epidemiological studies report prevalence of 0.3–0.8% in school-aged children, with a male predominance.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Chronic tic disorder
• Incorrect because this requires only motor OR only vocal tics for >12 months.
• Misconception: that “chronic” implies severity rather than absence of combined tics.
• Differentiator: TS mandates both motor and vocal tics.

B. Stereotypes
• Incorrect: stereotypies are rhythmic, prolonged, often in infants or ASD, and not suppressible in the same way.
• Misconception: equating any repetitive movement with tics.
• Differentiator: stereotypies lack the sudden, brief, suppressible nature of tics and absence of vocalizations.

D. Transient tic disorder
• Incorrect because duration here is 14 months (>12 months).
• Misconception: assuming any childhood tic is provisional.
• Differentiator: transient tic disorder requires resolution within one year.

Comparison Table

FeatureTourette SyndromeChronic Tic DisorderTransient Tic DisorderStereotypies
Motor tics≥2≥1≥1Yes (rhythmic, patterned)
Vocal tics≥100Rare
Duration>12 months>12 months<12 monthsVariable, often lifelong
Age of onset<18 years<18 years<18 yearsUsually <3 years
SuppressibilityYes (urge followed by relief)YesYesOften involuntary, not urge-based

Clinical Pearls

• First-line therapy for TS in children with impairing tics is Comprehensive Behavioral Intervention for Tics (CBIT).
• Common comorbidities include ADHD and OCD; screen routinely as they often drive impairment more than tics.
• Educate families that tic severity often peaks in early adolescence and declines in late teens.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Classifying any tic >6 months as Tourette—must be >12 months.
2. Failing to distinguish vocal from motor tics; chronic tic disorder excludes combined tics.
3. Misidentifying stereotypies (e.g., in autism) as tics—note differences in suppressibility and sensory premonitory urge.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. American Academy of Neurology (AAN), 2019 Practice Guideline (Pringsheim et al.):
– Recommendation: Aripiprazole and risperidone have Level A evidence for reducing tic severity in TS.
2. AAN, 2018 Behavioral Therapies Guideline (Piacentini et al.):
– Recommendation: Comprehensive Behavioral Intervention for Tics (CBIT) is Level A evidence for children and adults with TS.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Promotion 2018 exam.
Tic disorder classification is frequently tested as a standalone recall item or within clinical vignettes highlighting duration and tic types.

question_text: Q14. Sydenham chorea
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2021] Sydenham chorea is a post-streptococcal autoimmune movement disorder targeting basal ganglia circuits. The caudate nucleus and putamen modulate motor output via direct and indirect pathways; antibody-mediated dysfunction here causes rapid, irregular involuntary movements. It typically arises in school-age children 4–6 weeks after group A Streptococcus pharyngitis and represents a major Jones criterion for acute rheumatic fever. Molecular mimicry—cross-reaction between streptococcal M protein and neuronal antigens—underlies its pathogenesis. Clinicians must integrate rheumatologic features (arthritis, carditis) with choreiform movements to make an early diagnosis and prevent rheumatic heart disease progression.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Sydenham chorea fulfills a major criterion in the 2015 American Heart Association Revised Jones Criteria (Class I, Level C). Anti-streptococcal antibodies cross-react with basal ganglia neurons, disrupting dopaminergic-GABAergic transmission (Cunningham MW, 2012). MRI is usually normal; FDG-PET shows transient caudate hypermetabolism. Symptomatic treatment: haloperidol (0.01–0.05 mg/kg/day) or valproate (15 mg/kg/day) yields significant chorea reduction (Cardoso F et al., 2014). Small RCTs demonstrate that corticosteroids (prednisone 2 mg/kg/day tapered over 6 weeks) shorten symptom duration (McCreary MK et al., 2016). Long-term benzathine penicillin G every 4 weeks prevents recurrence and progression of rheumatic carditis (AHA Class I, Level B).

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. “Is primarily caused by Huntington’s disease”
• Huntington’s is an adult-onset autosomal dominant disorder (CAG repeat expansion in HTT) causing chorea plus progressive cognitive and psychiatric decline. Sydenham chorea occurs in children post-streptococcal infection.

C. “Is characterized by rigidity and bradykinesia”
• Rigidity and bradykinesia define parkinsonism (e.g., Parkinson disease). Chorea features hyperkinetic, irregular, non-rhythmic movements without sustained resistance to passive movement.

D. “Is an autoimmune disorder affecting the peripheral nerves”
• Guillain-Barré syndrome and chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy affect peripheral nerves, causing ascending weakness and sensory loss. Sydenham chorea is a central basal ganglia disorder causing involuntary movements, not peripheral neuropathy.

Comparison Table

FeatureSydenham ChoreaHuntington’s DiseaseParkinsonismGuillain-Barré Syndrome
Age of onset5–15 years30–50 years>60 yearsAny age
EtiologyPost-streptococcal autoimmunityHTT gene CAG expansionsNigrostriatal dopaminergic lossAutoimmune demyelination
Movement typeChorea (irregular, rapid)Chorea plus cognitive declineBradykinesia, rigidityNo involuntary movements
Associated findingsCarditis, arthritisDementia, psychiatric symptomsRest tremor, postural instabilityAscending paralysis, areflexia
Diagnostic testsASO titer, echocardiographyGenetic testing (HTT)Clinical, DaT-SCAN imagingCSF albuminocytologic dissociation

Clinical Pearls

• Screen for antistreptococcal titers (ASO, anti-DNase B) and perform echocardiography for silent carditis in any child with new-onset chorea.
• First-line symptomatic agents are valproate and haloperidol; consider corticosteroids or IVIG in severe or refractory cases.
• Maintain benzathine penicillin G prophylaxis every 4 weeks for ≥10 years or until age 21 to prevent recurrences and rheumatic heart disease.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Attributing pediatric chorea to psychogenic causes without investigating for post-streptococcal autoimmunity—always check infection history and ASO titers.
2. Confusing chorea with tics—Sydenham chorea is continuous, non-suppressible, and exacerbates with stress, unlike transient, suppressible tics.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- American Heart Association, 2015 Revised Jones Criteria: Sydenham chorea is a major criterion for acute rheumatic fever diagnosis (Class I, Level C evidence).
• World Heart Federation, 2017 Rheumatic Heart Disease Prophylaxis Guidelines: recommend intramuscular benzathine penicillin G every 4 weeks for secondary prophylaxis in patients with Sydenham chorea (Class I, Level B evidence).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Cross-reactive antibodies disrupt the balance between the direct (striatonigral) and indirect (striatopallidal) basal ganglia pathways, causing thalamocortical disinhibition and choreiform movements.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Molecular mimicry between group A streptococcal M protein and neuronal antigens (e.g., lysoganglioside) leads to anti-neuronal antibody production, complement activation, and dysfunction of basal ganglia neurons.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Obtain thorough history of streptococcal infection and rheumatic fever signs
2. Order ASO and anti-DNase B titers
3. Perform echocardiography for valvulitis
4. Neurological exam to document chorea; exclude alternative etiologies

Neuroimaging Pearls

Brain MRI is typically unremarkable; SPECT or FDG-PET may show transient hyperactivity in the caudate and putamen correlating with chorea severity.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

• Haloperidol: initiate 0.01–0.05 mg/kg/day in divided doses; monitor for extrapyramidal side effects.
• Valproate: 15 mg/kg/day; monitor liver function and platelet count.
• Corticosteroids: prednisone 2 mg/kg/day for 2–4 weeks with gradual taper over 6 weeks in severe cases.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Promotion 2021 exam. Sydenham chorea is frequently tested as a major Jones criterion; examiners often include distractors such as Huntington disease and parkinsonism to assess understanding of movement disorder classifications.

question_text: A 9-year-old boy, previously healthy, develops abnormal movements of the upper and lower limbs with gait instability. The family reports a 6-week history of runny nose. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2023] Sydenham chorea (SC) is an autoimmune-mediated movement disorder occurring 4–8 weeks after group A streptococcal pharyngitis. It involves basal ganglia dysfunction due to molecular mimicry between streptococcal antigens and neuronal tissue. Clinically, SC presents in children (mean age 5–15 years) with choreiform movements, hypotonia, emotional lability, and gait disturbances. Differentiating SC from other choreas relies on the temporal relationship to infection, laboratory evidence of recent streptococcal exposure (elevated ASO/anti-DNase B titers), and absence of systemic features seen in alternative diagnoses.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Sydenham chorea is recognized as one of the major Jones criteria for acute rheumatic fever in the American Heart Association’s 2015 Revised Rheumatic Fever Guidelines (LoE C). The 4–6-week latency period after pharyngitis, elevated anti-streptolysin O titers, and the absence of hepatic, hematologic, or structural brain abnormalities support SC. Kirvan et al. (J Neuroimmunol. 2006) demonstrated anti-basal ganglia autoantibodies in SC patients, confirming its immunopathogenesis. Management is primarily supportive; corticosteroids can shorten symptom duration (Bauer et al., Pediatr Neurol. 2002; LoE B), while valproate or haloperidol may control severe chorea. Long-term penicillin prophylaxis prevents recurrence.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Chorea-acanthocytosis
– Incorrect: Presents in young adults with neurodegeneration, orofacial dystonia, seizures, and peripheral acanthocytes.
– Misconception: All chorea in children is post-infectious.
– Differentiation: SC lacks acanthocytes, seizure activity, and orofacial biting.

C. Wilson’s disease
– Incorrect: Manifests in adolescents/adults with hepatic dysfunction, Kayser-Fleischer rings, psychiatric changes, and dystonia.
– Misconception: Wilson’s can present solely as chorea.
– Differentiation: Normal ceruloplasmin and no liver abnormalities in SC.

D. Essential tremor
– Incorrect: Characterized by bilateral, postural/action tremor of hands/head, improving with alcohol, without choreiform movements.
– Misconception: Any involuntary movement is tremor.
– Differentiation: SC movements are irregular, unpredictable chorea, not rhythmic tremor.

Comparison Table

FeatureSydenham ChoreaChorea-acanthocytosisWilson’s DiseaseEssential Tremor
Age of Onset5–15 years20–40 years10–25 yearsAny, often >40 years
Antecedent InfectionGroup A strep pharyngitis (4–8 weeks prior)NoneNoneNone
Movement TypeRapid choreiform movements, gait instabilityChorea + orofacial dystoniaDysarthria, dystonia, tremorRhythmic action/postural tremor
Lab Findings↑ ASO/anti-DNase B, ESR/CRP ↑Acanthocytes on PBS↓ Ceruloplasmin, ↑ urinary CuNormal labs
NeuroimagingUsually normalCaudate atrophyT2 basal ganglia hyperintensitiesNormal
TreatmentSupportive, steroids, penicillin ppxSupportive, chorea managementChelation (penicillamine)Propranolol, primidone

Clinical Pearls

• Sydenham chorea may present with hypotonia (“milkmaid’s grip”) and emotional lability.
• It is often self-limited over 2–6 months, but prophylactic penicillin is essential to prevent rheumatic carditis.
• In severe cases, corticosteroids accelerate resolution; anti-dopaminergic agents manage chorea but carry extrapyramidal risks.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Mislabeling chorea as tremor: chorea is arrhythmic, unpredictable, unlike rhythmic essential tremor.
2. Overlooking rheumatic carditis: always perform echocardiography in suspected SC to rule out subclinical valvulitis.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• American Heart Association, 2015 Revised Jones Criteria for Rheumatic Fever (LoE C): Sydenham chorea is a major manifestation; requires evidence of recent streptococcal infection.
• Pediatric Neurology Society, 2021 Consensus on Pediatric Movement Disorders (LoE B): Recommends corticosteroids for moderate-to-severe SC to reduce chorea duration.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Promotion 2023 exam. Sydenham chorea, as a major Jones criterion, is frequently tested in promotion and board exams, often emphasizing the latency period after streptococcal infection and differentiation from metabolic or genetic choreas.

question_text: A 9-year-old boy has a history of 14 months of vocal and motor tics, along with a history of OCD. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2019] - Cortico-striato-thalamo-cortical (CSTC) circuits: Disinhibition of basal ganglia outputs leads to tic generation.
• Dopaminergic hyperactivity in the striatum underlies motor and vocal tics.
• DSM-5 criteria require multiple motor tics and ≥1 vocal tic persisting >12 months with onset <18 years.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Tourette syndrome (TS) is defined in DSM-5 (APA, 2013) by the presence of ≥2 motor tics and ≥1 vocal tic for >12 months, with onset before age 18. This patient’s 14-month history of combined tics meets criteria, whereas transient tic disorder is <12 months and chronic motor tic disorder lacks vocal tics. OCD co-occurs in up to 50% of TS cases (Robertson MM et al., 2009). Structural MRI is usually normal, but volumetric studies show reduced caudate correlating with tic severity (Peterson BS et al., 2003). The American Academy of Neurology practice guideline (Pringsheim et al., 2019) recommends Comprehensive Behavioral Intervention for Tics (CBIT) first-line and antipsychotics (risperidone, aripiprazole) second-line.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Transient tic disorder
• Incorrect because tics in this disorder resolve within 12 months; here they persist 14 months.
C. Chronic motor tic disorder
• Incorrect because vocal tics are absent in chronic motor tic disorder; this patient has vocal tics.
D. Obsessive-compulsive disorder
• OCD is a common comorbidity but does not explain the presence of motor and vocal tics.

Comparison Table

FeatureTourette syndromeTransient tic disorderChronic motor tic disorderObsessive-compulsive disorder
Motor tics≥2Any≥1None
Vocal tics≥1OptionalNoneNone
Duration>12 months<12 months>12 monthsN/A
Age of onset<18 years<18 years<18 yearsVariable
Common comorbidity (OCD)Up to 50%RareRareCore feature

Clinical Pearls

- Always screen for ADHD and OCD in TS; comorbidities alter management strategy.
• CBIT (including habit reversal training) is first-line (Level A evidence, Piacentini et al., 2010).
• Low-dose risperidone (0.25–3 mg/day) or aripiprazole (2.5–10 mg/day) effectively reduce tic severity.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Mislabeling a >12-month tic disorder as “transient”—duration is the key differentiator.
2. Overlooking vocal tics and thus misdiagnosing chronic motor tic disorder.
3. Attributing all repetitive behaviors to OCD rather than recognizing distinct tic phenomenology.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- American Academy of Neurology (Pringsheim et al., 2019): CBIT first-line; antipsychotics second-line (Level A).
• European Society for the Study of Tourette Syndrome (Capriotti et al., 2021): Recommends deep brain stimulation for treatment-refractory TS (Level B).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

TS involves hyperactivity in the striatum (caudate nucleus, putamen) with insufficient prefrontal cortical inhibition, disrupting CSTC loops.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Excess dopaminergic transmission in basal ganglia lowers the threshold for unwanted motor patterns; GABAergic interneuron deficits further reduce inhibitory control.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Elicit detailed tic history: onset, type, frequency.
2. Apply DSM-5 criteria: ≥2 motor + ≥1 vocal tics >12 months.
3. Exclude secondary causes (e.g., PANDAS, medications).
4. Assess for ADHD, OCD, anxiety.
5. Initiate CBIT; consider pharmacotherapy if severe.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Risperidone: start 0.25 mg BID, titrate to 1–3 mg/day.
• Aripiprazole: 2.5–10 mg/day.
• Monitor weight, metabolic profile, and extrapyramidal symptoms.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Promotion 2019 exam. Tourette syndrome is frequently tested by contrasting tic duration (< vs >12 months) and presence of motor plus vocal tics.

question_text: A 12-year-old male patient had a runny nose two weeks ago. He presents with abnormal movements, and a video is attached for reference. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2021] The basal ganglia (caudate, putamen, subthalamic nucleus) modulate voluntary motor activity by inhibiting unwanted movements. Sydenham chorea is an autoimmune reaction after group A streptococcal pharyngitis, mediated by molecular mimicry targeting basal ganglia neurons. Symptoms arise 2–6 weeks post-infection and manifest as rapid, irregular, non‐purposeful movements that worsen with stress and disappear during sleep. It is one of the major Jones criteria for acute rheumatic fever. In contrast, Huntington disease presents in adults with progressive chorea plus cognitive decline; Tourette syndrome consists of suppressible, stereotyped tics; and Wilson disease features tremor, dystonia, and hepatic signs.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Sydenham chorea fits this case: a 2-week latent period after presumed streptococcal URI, pediatric onset, and choreiform movements. The 2015 American Heart Association revision of the Jones Criteria recognizes isolated chorea as a major criterion for acute rheumatic fever (Class IIa, Level C)1. Autoantibodies against streptococcal M protein cross‐react with basal ganglia antigens, causing neuronal dysfunction2. MRI is often normal or may show subtle basal ganglia T2 hyperintensities. Management includes penicillin prophylaxis and symptomatic therapy with valproic acid (10–15 mg/kg/day) or haloperidol (0.01–0.1 mg/kg/day), both shown to reduce chorea severity and duration3,4.

References:
1. Gewitz MH et al. Circulation. 2015;131(20):1806–1818.
2. Dale RC et al. Brain. 2005;128(Pt 2):413–424.
3. AHA 2015 Jones Criteria update.
4. Oliveira GH et al. J Child Neurol. 2022;37(7):1304–1310.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Huntington disease
• Onset in 30–50 years with autosomal dominant CAG expansion and progressive dementia.
• Misconception: pediatric chorea implies Huntington’s.
• Differentiator: genetic testing confirms CAG repeat; juvenile form causes rigidity/bradykinesia.

C. Tourette syndrome
• Characterized by brief, suppressible motor/vocal tics with premonitory urges.
• Misconception: tics are random hyperkinetic movements.
• Differentiator: tics are stereotyped, wax and wane, and associated with OCD/ADHD.

D. Wilson disease
• Copper accumulation causes tremor, dystonia, hepatic dysfunction, and Kayser–Fleischer rings.
• Misconception: youth movement disorders equal Wilson’s.
• Differentiator: low ceruloplasmin, elevated urinary copper, liver enzyme abnormalities.

Comparison Table

FeatureSydenham ChoreaHuntington DiseaseTourette SyndromeWilson Disease
Age of Onset5–15 years30–50 years5–10 years10–20 years
EtiologyPost-strep autoimmuneAD CAG-repeat expansionMultifactorialATP7B mutation
Movement TypeIrregular choreaChoreiform + dystoniaStereotyped ticsTremor, dystonia, rigidity
Associated FindingsPharyngitis historyCognitive decline, psychiatricOCD/ADHDHepatic dysfunction, KF rings
Diagnostic Tests↑ASO/anti-DNase BGenetic testing (CAG repeats)Clinical, normal labsLow ceruloplasmin, ↑urine Cu

Clinical Pearls

- Sydenham chorea can occur as an isolated major Jones criterion; always perform echocardiography to detect silent carditis.
• Long‐term benzathine penicillin G (every 4 weeks) prevents recurrences and rheumatic heart disease.
• Valproic acid is preferred for symptomatic relief due to fewer extrapyramidal side effects compared to neuroleptics.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Confusing suppressible tics (Tourette) with chorea: chorea is nonrhythmic, non-stereotyped, and lacks premonitory urges.
• Neglecting the latent period: chorea may present weeks post–streptococcal infection without concurrent pharyngitis.
• Omitting cardiac evaluation: silent carditis occurs in up to 50% of Sydenham chorea cases.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. American Heart Association. Revision of the Jones Criteria for the Diagnosis of Acute Rheumatic Fever. Circulation. 2015;131(20):1806–1818.
Recommendation: Isolated Sydenham chorea qualifies as a major criterion (Class IIa, Level C).
2. Oliveira GH et al. Valproate vs Haloperidol in Sydenham Chorea: A Randomized Controlled Trial. J Child Neurol. 2022;37(7):1304–1310.
Finding: Valproic acid (15 mg/kg/day) led to faster symptom resolution and fewer adverse effects than haloperidol (0.05 mg/kg/day) (Level I evidence).

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Promotion 2021 exam. Sydenham chorea is frequently tested under pediatric movement disorders and rheumatic fever. Examinees should recognize the post‐streptococcal latent period, choreiform movement characteristics, and the Jones criteria for acute rheumatic fever.

question_text: An elderly female patient wakes up with abnormal left arm and leg involuntary movements. Before she slept, she had no complaints. She presented to the ER, where a CT brain was normal, and an MRI stroke protocol was done. Later, the involuntary movement improved. Where do you expect to find the abnormality in the MRI?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2022] • The subthalamic nucleus (STN) is a pivotal node in the indirect basal ganglia pathway: it sends excitatory glutamatergic projections to the globus pallidus interna (GPi).
• Lesion of the contralateral STN (often a lacunar infarct) reduces GPi inhibitory output to the thalamus, producing hyperkinetic movements (hemiballismus/hemichorea).
• Hemiballismus presents acutely with flinging, high-amplitude movements of the proximal limbs and often improves spontaneously as edema resolves.

Evidence-Based Analysis

The correct answer, B. Sub-thalamic, corresponds to infarction of the subthalamic nucleus, the classic neuroanatomical substrate for acute hemiballismus. In a landmark case series by Kim JS et al. (Stroke. 2001;32(7):1238–1242), 21 of 23 patients with unilateral hemiballismus had diffusion-weighted MRI (DWI) evidence of a contralateral STN lesion. The American Heart Association/American Stroke Association (AHA/ASA) 2018 guidelines recommend urgent MRI-DWI in stroke-like presentations when CT is non-diagnostic (Class I; Level of Evidence A), given its >90% sensitivity for small deep infarcts. Subcortical infarcts in the pons, midbrain, or medulla yield distinct clinical syndromes (e.g., cranial nerve deficits, ocular motor signs, bulbar palsies) rather than pure hyperkinetic movements.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Midbrain
– A midbrain infarct typically produces oculomotor deficits (e.g., vertical gaze palsy), contralateral ataxia (Red nucleus), or parkinsonian features (substantia nigra).
– Misconception: attributing any basal ganglia–adjacent lesion to hemiballismus.
– Differentiator: midbrain lesions spare the indirect pathway node (STN).

C. Pons
– Pontine strokes manifest with contralateral hemiparesis, facial weakness, ataxia, or “crossed” syndromes (e.g., Millard-Gubler) rather than choreiform movements.
– Misconception: deep brainstem lesions universally cause movement disorders.
– Differentiator: pons lacks direct involvement in basal ganglia motor modulation.

D. Medulla
– Medullary infarcts cause bulbar signs (dysphagia, dysphonia), Horner syndrome, or contralateral body sensory loss (e.g., Wallenberg syndrome).
– Misconception: small vessel strokes everywhere can cause hemiballismus.
– Differentiator: medulla has no role in the indirect basal ganglia circuitry.

Comparison Table

LocationTypical PresentationImaging Finding
Subthalamic nucleusContralateral hemiballismus/hemichoreaDWI hyperintense focal lesion in STN
MidbrainOculomotor palsy, contralateral ataxia, parkinsonismMRI T2/DWI lesion in midbrain tegmentum
PonsHemiparesis, facial weakness, ataxia, “crossed” signsPontine infarct on DWI/T2
MedullaBulbar dysfunction, sensory loss, Horner syndromeMedullary infarct on MRI

Clinical Pearls

• Hemiballismus is most often caused by a small lacunar infarct in the contralateral subthalamic nucleus.
• CT may be normal in the acute phase; MRI-DWI within hours is essential for diagnosis.
• Symptoms often improve over days to weeks as peri-infarct edema subsides; pharmacotherapy (e.g., haloperidol) is reserved for severe or persistent cases.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Assuming large cortical lesions cause hemiballismus—small STN infarcts are the classic etiology.
2. Relying solely on CT to rule out stroke in movement disorders—CT sensitivity for lacunar STN infarcts is <30%.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• AHA/ASA 2018 Guidelines for Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke:
– Recommendation: Obtain MRI with DWI in patients with suspected stroke and normal CT (Class I; Level of Evidence A).
• Wardlaw JM et al., “Imaging in Stroke: Current and Emerging Techniques,” Lancet Neurol. 2017;16(6):361–376:
– Meta-analysis demonstrated DWI sensitivity of >90% vs ≤30% for CT in detecting lacunar infarcts.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The STN lies ventral to the thalamus at the diencephalic–mesencephalic junction. It receives cortical input via the hyperdirect pathway and projects excitatory fibers to the GPi, modulating thalamocortical output. Lesioning the STN disinhibits thalamic nuclei, causing hyperkinesia.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Loss of STN excitatory drive reduces GPi-mediated GABAergic inhibition of the ventrolateral thalamus, leading to excessive thalamocortical activation and involuntary, high-amplitude proximal limb movements characteristic of hemiballismus.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical recognition of acute hemiballismus/hemichorea.
2. Non-contrast CT to exclude hemorrhage (often normal in lacunar strokes).
3. MRI stroke protocol with DWI, FLAIR, and SWI to identify small deep infarcts—focus on STN region.
4. Vascular risk factor management and symptomatic therapy if movements are disabling.

Neuroimaging Pearls

• DWI is most sensitive for acute ischemia in deep structures within minutes of onset.
• STN infarcts appear as 5–10 mm hyperintense foci on axial DWI, often missed on CT or conventional T2.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Promotion 2022 exam. Hyperkinetic movement disorders are frequently tested in stroke localization vignettes, emphasizing the classic STN lesion in hemiballismus presentations.
